title: brexit voters second referendum the sun says
story: Parliament this week sent them a clear message — their hopes to overturn the biggest democratic mandate in our country’s history will come to nothing.But now they have turned their guns on Brexit-supporting Labour MPs who have put constituents and country above their pathetic party’s posturing.These low-grade nobodies are already so bloated with self-importance that they’re happy to say they know better than million Leave voters.And they DARE to target MPs for the crime of voting for what their constituents want It’s exactly the sort of ideological purity battle Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour specialises in. The Tories need to show they’re above that.We don’t agree with much of Nick Boles’s plan for a Brexit so soft as to be barely Brexit at all. This week’s amendment, co-signed by Boles and Yvette Cooper, could have holed the whole operation below the waterline.But that does not mean he should be deselected. The Tory party has always been a broad church and it serves as a better party of government when pragmatism is its guiding force.For the first time in months, the Conservatives have shown the sort of professionalism and unity that the public expects of them.They must keep it together.IT is an outrage that speedboat killer Jack Shepherd continues to claim legal aid despite refusing toto Britain.Justice Secretary David Gauke cannot simply put his hands in the air and claim he’s powerless to do anything.Everybody has a right to a fair trial, and that often means help with legal costs. But how anybody on the run can be entitled to taxpayers’ cash is absolutely beyond us.Gauke has form for dodging tough decisions. His plans to reform Parole Board transparency in the wake of the John Worboys fiasco are still in a holding pattern.He has been renowned as a safe pair of hands for years.That reputation is rapidly disintegrating.A STONED teenager drives his parents’ Audi and kills two people — weeks after being stopped for suspected drug-driving.You’d probably expect the lout to spend some time at Her Maj’s pleasure. You’d at least expect him to be charged with manslaughter, or death by dangerous driving.But no. The coppers’ son from swanky Ascot walked free from court with barely a slap on the wrist.Would that happen to a -year-old council estate kid We doubt it. The law looks an ass. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: fiona onasanya should resign immediately
story: Two years ago, his certainty that she would make a good MP could not have been more adamant.“‘I urge all of you — do everything you possibly can to get this ­wonderful woman elected as the MP,” he said at the time.Just to be clear, this is the same “wonderful woman” who has been given a jail sentence for lying when she was caught speeding, saying it was not her who was driving.On July , , at .pm, a speed camera caught her car doing mph in a mph zone.A week later, a notice of intended prosecution form was sent to ­Onasanya.Had she replied honestly, telling police she was the driver, she would probably have received three points on her licence and a fine.Instead, she claimed it was not her driving — and during questioning at Bedfordshire Police headquarters,she remained completely silent, which is a bit of an odd way to act.It’s not great for a newly elected MP to get a speeding fine, granted.But it does happen and it’s not the end of the world. So why lie Some people have been asking this weekjail is the best punishment for a speeding fine. But let’s be clear: She is not going to prison for speeding — she is going to prison for perverting the course of justice by lying about who was driving her car.That would be bad enough for an average citizen. But Onasanya is not an average citizen. She is a solicitor — and also an MP.An MP is known by the title ­“Honourable” for a reason: There is a code of conduct outlined for MPs which includes, among other things, integrity and honesty.Any MP has even more obligation than the average person to set a good example and to take responsibility for their actions — both of which she has failed, spectacularly, to do. She has acted asshe is above the law, which is simply not acceptable for someone whose job is to uphold the law.She no longer deserves the privilege of representing anyone in the legal or parliamentary system and it is clear to any right-thinking ­person that she should be struck off as a solicitor — and resign as an MP.It is her refusal to do this immediately which is the most astonishing thing about this story.That, plus Corbyn’s lack of ­leadership in not insisting she resign as soon as she was found guilty.By all accounts, it sounds like she was out of her depth as an MP from the get go. For a start, constituents complained she was uncontactable.She also spent £, of taxpayer’s money in seven months on “expenses” and was caught on video ­pretending to snort “cocaine”, which isn’t exactly a great look for an MP.The trial judge concluded the “truth comes a very distant second to your personal ambition, doesn’t it ”Whether or not that’s true, it is hard not to conclude, in the face of the evidence against her, that her refusal to resign as an MP is rooted in the £, salary it yields.But how is she going to help her constituents from prison One argument being made about her being sent to jail is that she is clearly not a danger to society, which is true. But the problem for the courts is thatyou take an oath to tell the truth, then fail to do so, it has to be considered a serious offence — and punished accordingly.Without a deterrent to stop people lying through their teeth, the justice system would collapse.Let’s face it, there is nothing about this story that makes Onasanya look good.She is going to have an ­electronic tag when she comes out.No doubt she is massively regretting not owning up to speeding in the first place — and taking the consequences.Her le is now in tatters.But resigning as an MP now might help her claw back a tiny bit of respect for finally doing the right thing. As a solicitor and an MP, she needs to take full responsibility for her actions.IT’S shocking that Bonita Baxter, a heavily pregnant woman with a serious heart condition, was forced to sit on an AE floor at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham for five hours after patients and visitors refused to give up their seats.Clearly, manners are no longer important to this nation.But the real issue is that the hospital was so overcrowded that, given the five-hour wait, no one was going to give up their seat.AE departments continue to be overcrowded in part because we continue to abuse the NHS, turning up to AE for anything from drunkenness to a broken fingernail.Anyone who has ever had to pay for their healthcare, as they do in North America, would respect our health service much, much more.In the meantime, we need to put measures in place to make sure that people start valuing what they have.There should be fines for people who don’t attend GP and hospital appointments.And AE should start turning away anything other than genuine emergencies.T’S heart-breaking, isn’t it, ­listening to Vicky Pattison blaming herself for the fact her fiancé, John Noble, had “grown close to” other women during a boys’ trip to Dubai “When something like this happens, you blame yourself and I did question myself. MaybeI was thinner he wouldn’t have done what he did,” she said on TV on Wednesday.Apparently, this charmer actually blamed her – and her size – saying that he was “set up” to cheat because of it. Vicky, darling,you are reading this: It’s not your fault he cheated. And no amount of dieting would have stopped him.A cheater’s always going to cheat.You need to take some time out to focus on yourself and decide not to be around people who make you feel bad about yourself. There is so much pressure on women today.There is so much emphasis on how they look and how other people see them, rather than a focus on real values, like the size of your brain.So I suppose it’s easy to understand how Vicky concluded that her appearance might be the “problem”.When the reality is just that she picked an a***hole to go out with.I ABHOR fat-shaming, and rudeness. And I have zero sympathy for the woman who refused to sit between two overweight passengers on a United Airlines flight from Las Vegas to New York.She caused a horrible scene and loudly called them “big pigs”, which is truly shocking.But luckily the shame was all hers, as her tirade went viral on social media – and she was thrown off the flight.It’s also true thatyou book a flight then you are entitled to the seat you’ve booked, andsomeone is taking up half of yours that’s not fair.But this issue should be dealt with by the airline, not passengers.Many airlines have an “obesity policy”. American Airlines, for example, requires passengers to purchase a second seatthey need a seatbelt extension and their body “extends more than one inch beyond the outermost edge of the arm rest”.I can imagine it’s a dficult and embarrassing rule to enforce – but it’s better than people taking matters into their ownhands.For once, I can say I did not stray, not even so much as once.THE Europeans screaming that the Irish backstop must remain are deluded.No Deal will affect Europe as much as – and in some cases, more than – the UK.And when the French farmers realise they can’t get their cheese across the border before it rots, and the Spanish – who sell more goods and services to the UK than it buys – are stranded with decaying goods, and when German car sales slump because tarfs make them too expensive, I predict riots across Europe.And then Michael Barnier will have a small dose of the pain he has inflicted on our PM.The reality is that citizens of these European countries, whose jobs will be under threat by No Deal, will not give a hootthere is or isn’t a hard border in Ireland.And frankly, all companies collect VAT for the Government and PAYE for them, so why not let them do the same for tarfs and be their own custom offices The Government can audit them once every three months, then the problem is solved.APPARENTLY, dog-walking in Tehran has been outlawed by the Islamic government in a crackdown against pet ownership.Dog owners will even face penaltiesspotted carrying their pets in a car.Tehran’s chief of police, Brigadier-General Hossein Rahimi, said the ban had been introduced because dogs “create fear and anxiety” among members of the public.Ironically, my experience is that dogs create exactly the opposite reaction.But what do you expect from a country that doesn’t allow women to initiate orce, dance or report a rape .Our country might be crazy at the moment, but let’s all breathe a sigh of relief we live here, rather than there.Our journalists title: jacob rees mogg brexit compromise
story: It would mean extending the transition period from the end of  to December  but with the UK following EU rules and paying an extra £billion into Brussels coffers.It would also mean replacing the Irish backstop with technological solutions while leaving the option open of exiting the EU on World Trade Organisation rules –a free-trade deal has not been struck.The idea was named after housing minister Kit Malthouse, who brought the two sides together in secret. Here, leading Conservative Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg offers his view:THE EU has taken an almost religious approach to Britain’s latest move towards securing a Brexit deal.The compromise put forward by my fellow MP Kit Malthouse has been immediately dismissed and any prospect of further negotiation turned away. The mighty EU has spoken and will not be gainsaid.In negotiating the compromise, both Leavers and Remainers made concessions. This has led to criticism from their supporters, as I found in my weekly radio show on LBC.Callers felt that I had become a “snowflake” in my willingness to see £billion of taxpayers’ money spent without giving us any advantage in future negotiations.The legal basis for the EU demanding money is weak. A House of Lords report came to the conclusion that while there could be a moral obligation, under UK, EU and international law there was no valid or forceful claim.The only motive for paying is to secure a good future deal, rather than to pay a ransom for our freedom.Yet I have come to the conclusion that leaving on March  is at risk and exiting the EU is a prize worth paying for and on which thewill be great.Unfortunately, in spite of the Referendum result, the majority of MPs are reluctant to see the UK part from the EU and at the least want terms that mirror our membership.This may well not be the view of most voters, who seem to welcome the clean break and are not fearful of the scare stories.It is, therefore, crucial to ensure the fears of those who are far from enthusiastic Brexiteers are assuaged. This is where the Malthouse Compromise comes in.By offering money and making the prospect of a No Deal Brexit unlikely, possible moderate former Remainers are willing to avoid Parliamentary tactics that would frustrate our departure.They can accept the replacement of the backstop, which could keep us tied in to the EU’s rules and courts forever, with a routine trade agreement based on existing processes commonly used around the world.This would not hamper the development of a future relationship which would be discussed once we have left. Although in these discussions we would lose the leverage of cash, we would not be squeezed by the backstop.The second stage of the compromise is that the implementation period could be extended by one year. Currently the withdrawal agreement proposes a maximum of two years.In this time we would remain subject to EU laws and what follows, but it makes the prospect of not finalising a future relationship less likely, which gives comfort to those who are determined to avoid No Deal.In my view, an extra  months of vassalage after  years is an unwelcome but not unaffordable price to pay. Critics may ask why Brexiteers want to lessen the chance of a No Deal departure — and the reason is simple.Regardless of the folly of Project Fear, which becomes more preposterous by the day, the Parliamentary arithmetic means we must either lessen the prospect by compromise or it will be done by sharp practice in the House of Commons.This could lead to delay or even no Brexit at all. This would destroy any remaining trust of politicians in our constitutional settlement, it would show reckless contempt for voters, yet the Brexit-denying amendment put forward by Yvette Cooper last week was only defeated by  votes.As with all compromises, Malthouse is not perfect but is enough for each side of the argument in the UK to accept.The question remains, will the EU response be positive  So far, it has not.This has always been at the heart of the debate, and in a way a compelling reason for going. Is the EU a Mafia-style organisation that has to punish countries that do not subscribe to its religion Their response to the Malthouse Compromise and the PM’s request to re-open the text will answer this question. It must be clear to the EU that the current withdrawal agreement will not do.Defeated in the Commons by the largest margin ever achieved in the lower house on Government business, it is simply too one-sided and allows too great a triumph to the EU.If the EU were to insist on its inalterability requiring the punishment of a recalcitrant, freedom-loving nation then it will reveal its true and barbarous colours. It would be evident on its own that we are right to leave.How much better it would bethis were wrong and that in fact the EU is the civilised organisation it claims to be — respecting democracy, the nation state and constitutional procedures. In a few weeks we will know.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: theresa may brexit negotiations poker
story: Last week’s Commons victory over Remainers — a surprise to everyone including the PM herself — has given her a strong hand to play for Britain.The PM has the unexpected authority of Parliament to scrub the hated Northern Ireland backstop. Her squabbling party has called a temporary truce. And nobody, including the EU, wants Jeremy Corbyn to take control.Even Labour MPs are rallying behind her — at a price. And working-class voters have given the Tories a healthy seven-point lead. They might even win a snap election.Played skilfully, this could win a deal that satisfies both Remainers and Leavers.Yet there are fears Mrs May will use it to revive her wretched Chequers plan, which sparked the resignations of Boris Johnson and David Davis, or the botched deal thrown out last month by a -vote margin.She has made a worrying start by apparently binning the No Deal card — the only one that truly scares the EU. Mrs May has no intention of playing this ace — and never had.There are other worrying signs.This showdown with EU hardliners requires fresh thinking and shrewd advice from seasoned players. Crawford Falconer, an ex-World Trade Organisation ambassador, was recruited by the Brexit department for precisely these skills.Indeed, he is the ONLY person in the Government machine who has ever negotiated a trade deal.Yet bafflingly, Mrs May is keeping this star player on the sidelines.Instead, she will fly to Brussels with Whitehall mandarin Olly Robbins, the pro-EU fanatic who plunged Britain into the backstop trap she is now under pressure to escape from.Robbins hates Brexit and has privately warned the PM this is Mission Impossible.Mrs May — herself a Remainer who has never grasped the case for Brexit — will be joined by trusted “deputy PM” David Lidington, a dyed-in-the-wool Brussels worshipper.In such company, even the inclusion in her team of a thundering Brexiteer Attorney-General Geoffrey Cox is only mildly reassuring.Mrs May is notoriously stubborn. She can also be devious.After nearly three years, even her closest political colleagues — who can be counted on one hand with a couple of missing digits — have no idea what her Brexit might look like.Voters are increasingly irritated by this foot-dragging.Why should we remain part of an organisation that wants to punish us by stealing Gibraltar, Northern Ireland and our car industry Nobody who watched the brutal humiliation of poor little Greece will be surprised. This tragic and insolvent nation should never have been admitted to the EU, still less the Eurozone.Only with the assistance of US banking giant Goldman Sachs — “The Vampire Squid” — got them in under the wire. Once inside, they launched a borrowing and spending binge which ended in tears in the  crash.Greece might have flourished as a cheap but lovely tourist economy. Instead, it is now being cruelly tormented by Brussels and lumbered with multi-billion euros debts it can never repay.Greece symbolises all that is wrong with arrogant Brussels — the catastrophic Euro, inflexible economic policies and mass unemployment for under-s.Above all, there is the sneering contempt of unsackable Eurocrats for the million people they rule from subsidised ivory towers.Theresa May is a poor negotiator who never truly believed No Deal is better than a bad deal.Without this implicit threat, Brussels will give little and demand much in . It would be a pleasure to eat my words and watch Mrs May play a blinder.She can use her good luck to land a historic victory. Or she can blink and condemn Britain to colony status, paying billions more into EU coffers while being led by the nose on trade deal promises that never materialise.In which case, forget about that snap election fantasy.The Conservative Party would never be forgiven by the .million voters who voted Brexit — or those who wish they had.SECURITY CHIEFS are dusting off Cold War plans anticipating a Soviet nuclear strike to whisk the Queen to safety in the event of . . .  er . . . a No Deal Brexit.Presumably The Mall will be cleared of traffic and used as a landing strip to fly Her Maj out before revolutionary Remainers string her up for supporting Brexit.The only question is whether she will go quietly.The royals refused to leave London even after Buckingham Palace was bombed during the Second World War.This Project Fear nonsense is even more insane than the idea that thousands will die of fruit shortages.To quote Corporal Jones: “Don’t panic!!”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories no general election june
story: The public is sick to the back teeth of politicians seemingly unable to carry out the task set for them twice over in a Referendum and a General Election: to take us out of the European Union, with a good deal or a managed clean break.For the first time in months, Parliament last week took a giant step in that direction – and the Prime Minister and the Cabinet should be focussed on delivering the changes to the backstop that the Commons demanded.That should be the only thing on anybodys mind in Westminster.Once we are free of the EU’s shackles, the priority must be to supercharge the British economy, with a new Chancellor and a reinvigorated party setting a course for Britain to become ever more competitive on the global stage.The Party can start on genuine reform of the Health Service, and allow British businesses to be at the forefront of new technology.The Tories must show real progress on housing and welfare reform.Nobody in the Government should imagine they’ll romp to victory in an election just because they’re up against Jeremy Corbyn’s Venezuela-flavoured socialism.The Tories shouldn’t give a single thought to an election this summer.But they must start building a track record that can win a General Election in the years to come.NO doubt about it, Nissan’s decision not to build the X-Trail in Sunderland is a blow to UK Plc.But it is not, as inexplicably smug Remainers are crowing, entirely due to Brexit.It’s as much about Brits increasingly not buying diesel cars as it is about our future trading relationships with the Continent.And the joy with which some on the left are greeting the news is perverse. Do they not want Britain to succeed Do they not see that their bizarre, condescending attitude is EXACTLY why they lost in  THE rocketing suicide rate amongst teenagers is nothing short of a national crisis.And the solution MUST involve the social media firms who are profiting from youngsters’ suffering.They have been given quite enough warning that they are not doing enough to protect vulnerable kids.They have said for years that they just need a bit more time, and that they’d fix the problem themselves.Well, they’ve failed.Government has no choice but to step in – and it needs a concerted effort from the Education, Health and Culture Departments.One more tragic death is one too many.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remainer lies no deal anarchy
story: It’s not just the latest cobblers they seized on about the Queen being whisked to safety from rioting hordes descending on Buckingham Palace when food and medicines run out.It’s David Cameron pretending back in  that a Remain vote would empower him to fix the EU, asBrussels was remotely interested in reform.It’s George Osborne’s Project Fear tosh about an immediate crash after a Leave vote. title: half of brits are going to be short sighted after spending too much time looking at phones
story: David Allamby said half the population could have myopia by  given the amount of time children are spending with their phones – up from  per cent now.One in ten could be at risk of torn retinas or even losing their sight.Mr Allamby of Focus Clinics said Ministers had to encourage children to put down their devices and get “outside”.A survey in Ireland three years ago found the proportion of kids suffering from myopia has doubled from . per cent to . per cent in the past  years.He said: “We are sleepwalking into an epidemic.“Screen time isn’t just affecting the mental health of school children it could also be ruining their eyesight too. We face a tsunami of short-sightedness.”Academics argue that modern lestyles are putting a huge strain on the ciliary muscle – which ends up ening the eye. This in turn increases the risk of glaucoma, retinal tears and even detachment.Mr Allamby said the concern was the growing risk of Brits developing problems at a younger age. “The younger these problems start, the more serious they become at a later date.”Experts warn that modern lestyles – at-desk working and a lack of daylight – has led to a sharp rise in eyesight issues around the world.Nearly  per cent of  year-old conscripts in South Korea were found to have myopia.The Sun on Saturday revealed Chief Medical Officer Dame Sally Davies will recommend limiting kids to two-hours-a-time on their devices.Schools Minister Nick Gibb has also separately called for a ban on pupils taking smartphones into school.Digital Minister Margot James is also later today expected to confirm a bid to force social media firms by law to sign a code of conduct protecting young and vulnerable users.

title: tourist snaps seal poo new zealand usb
story: Vets took a slab of faeces from a leopard seal and had it stored in a freezer for a year before researchers started to analyse the mass for scientic research.But while sting the scat from feathers, seaweed and other junk they discovered something large and hard inside - a memory stick.Incredibly, after drying it out for a few weeks they were able to access all of its contents - including photos of sea lions at Porpoise Bay in Caitlins, as well as a video of a mum and baby frolicking in the shallows.The only clue of the person filming was the nose of a blue kayak shting through the waters, and a red and black boot poking out on the side of the boat.The footage is thought to have been taken in November , when a local vet checking on the health of a skinny seal picked up a sample.Seal faeces is said to be as good as gold for researchers, who can use the faeces to assess the health and diet of the animals.Volunteer Jodie Warren, who analysed the scat, was unimpressed by the holidaymaker in question. “It is very worrying that these amazing Antarctic animals have plastic like this inside them, she told the NIWA.The National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research said theof the USB stick would come with a price - a new sample of scat to continue their research.They added: The more we can find out about these creatures, the more we can ensure they are looked after.

title: steam treatment enlarged prostate
story: Current hour-long ops see heated metal put into the urethra and used to cut the prostate — risking incontinence and impotence.But a new therapy for the non-cancerous ailment uses a tube to blast steam at affected glands.  It shrinks them by up to a third, has fewer side effects and takes  minutes. title: twins survive surgery in the womb
story: The tots, now one, were given just a five per cent chance of survival after being diagnosed with rare Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome.It meant they shared the same placenta, affecting the blood they each received.Tabitha was  weeks pregnant when she had the pioneering op in Birmingham Women’s Hospital and needed weekly scans afterwards.The illustrator, , from Evesham, Worcs, said: “It was asthe world would stand still until I’d hear them confirm two heart beats.”“As well as being scanned weekly, I had a  minute long MRI scan to checkthe girls had any neurological damage - it took so long because they were both wriggling around so much that the radiographers struggled to get a still picture!”Now,  months on, the whole family is settling in well but now want to thank those who helped bring Isla and Jemima.Tabitha gave birth at  weeks and it was six weeks before the girls were allowed home.Husband Ben, , is now fundraising for charity TAMBA and has a JustGiving page under his name.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rolf harris walks primary school waves confronted teacher
story: The shamed former TV star, , was snapped outside his home today after he was told to leave by the head teacher of the school in Maidenhead, Berks.A witness, who took pictures of Harris stalking the grounds, told the Mirror: “I couldn’t believe what I was seeing.”The disgraced entertainer - who served three years in prison for a string of historical sex offences - shook hands with the head teacher before he was ordered off the site, the paper says.Richard Jarrett, head of Oldfield Primary School, insisted Harris had no access to the pupils and informed the police.But parents are outraged that he was able to wave and smile at their children.Mr Jarrett said: “We’ve got a wood sculptor working close to the road at the moment and Rolf Harris lives near to the school.He must have seen him [the sculptor] and come into the school area.He had no access to the children whatsoever.Harris explained that he was there to pick up some wood from the sculptor - but Mr Jarrett told him: You need to go.Askedhe was concerned about the paedo waving at children, the teacher replied: I was not there at the time to stop him waving at the children.”Shamed Animal Hospital star Harris was sentenced in June  to five years nine months in prison for a dozen indecent assaults against four teenage girls between  and .He was released on license after three years in May  - with his sentence running out in March next year.Harris is thought to have been placed on the Sex Offenders Register - but it is not clearhe will have breached this by entering the school grounds.Aussie Rolf was photographed outside the school at about noon on Tuesday wearing a red jacket similar to the one he wore in his infamous mugshot.The passer-by who took the snaps said: I could not believe what I was seeing. A convicted paedophile should not be in the grounds of a primary school.“He was waving at the children through the window. I think they were on lunch or maybe in class.They were waving back at him and clearly had no idea who he was.”And a furious mum of two said: “For him to just be able to freely walk in is not a good thing.If you’re a paedophile you can’t be going near a school. I’m disgusted.”The Ministry of Justice said: “When sex offenders are released they are subject to strict licence conditions and are liable to be ed to custody for breaching them.We are looking into these reports and will take appropriate action.”A police spokesman said: “Thames Valley Police was called to Oldfield Primary School at around .pm today.“A report was made that a man was on the site of the school.An officer attended the scene but no offence was committed. No arrests were made.”Harris was not at home to comment, according to the Mirror.

title: spanish patrol boat stand off navy gibraltar
story: The episode had echoes of historic maritime victories against the Spanish by Admiral Lord Nelson at Trafalgar in  and Sir Francis Drake against the Armada in .In yesterday’s incident tiny HMS Sabre was involved in manoeuvres with a Royal Navy RHIB, when the Spanish vessel - the Tornado - blatantly sailed into the training drill yesterday morning where it stayed for two hours.As it passed into territorial waters the Spanish national anthem could be heard over Channel , a maritime communications frequency but it was not clear where it had come from.The captain of HMS Sabre warned the intruder away but it did not impact on the exercise.A Royal Navy insider confirmed the Spanish national anthem had been heard by radio operators at the Royal Navy base on Gibraltar.A source said:HMS Sabre politely requested the Spanish vessel, which is a good bit larger than she is, to leave Gibraltars territorial waters with a sovereignty warning. They extend for three miles around Gibraltar and initially it ignored the request which was made several times but she did eventually sail away after a couple of hours.Screenshots from shipping websites show how Tornado left the Spanish port of Ceuta yesterday morning before doubling back and heading towards Gibraltars Europa Point, clearly entering the exercise area.The rocky outcrop has been a British territory for more than  years and has been hotly disputed with Madrid and tensions have risen in the run up to Brexit.Last week colony in the UK and the EU launched into a new war of words over the Rock today as Gibraltar was branded a draft laws to give visa-free travel to Britons after March th.Downing Street swtly moved to slap down the jibe which is the latest ploy by Spain to take advantage of Brexit to stake its claim on the Rock.In yesterdays exercise - which was widely advertised by the Gibraltar authorities - ships were warned that a high speed manoeuvring and blank firing would take place.Passing ships who needed to contact the Royal Navy vessels involved were advised to use Channel  - which the Spanish did to broadcast their national anthem.A source in Gibraltar told The Sun:Spain is supposed to be a NATO ally but it now does this during an exercise - a clear infringement of Gibraltar territorial waters and it comes just weeks after they let Russian ships use their ports when they were asked not to.HMS Sabre issued a sovereignty warning to Tornado after it entered Gibraltar territorial waters and ordered her to leave immediately - there was an exercise going on and they would have known plus channel  was used to broadcast their national anthem. Its a clear provocation from Spain.Last night the Royal Navy referred all enquiries to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.In a statement the FCO said:We can confirm an incursion by the Spanish navy occurred this morning. As with all incursions, the Royal Navy challenged the vessel. When challenged, the Spanish navy vessel subsequently left British Gibraltar Territorial Waters. Incursions are a violation of sovereignty, not a threat to it.We have no doubt about our sovereignty over Gibraltar. The UK will never enter into arrangements under which the people of Gibraltar would pass under the sovereignty of another state against their wishes, nor enter into a process of sovereignty negotiations with which Gibraltar is not content.”The Spanish Government in Madrid and the Spanish Embassy in London was also contacted for comment but there was no immediate reply.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: toby carvery customer sparks debate about perfect roast potato with complaint about overcooked spuds
story: Laura Heskett was gutted when her party were offered the blackened potatoes as part of their £. all you can eat roast dinner in Ramsgate, Kent.Alongside a photo of the charred chow on Facebook, Laura fumed: “Toby Carvery expecting us to eat roasties like this!”But while some roast lovers backed Laura’s moan – others were quick to give her a mouthful.Maria Parker added: “Roasties….Crematies surely ”But Janet Rankin joked: “I’d eat them well done.”Ria Baldoc said: “I must be weird I love potatoes like that!”Gary Hillman said: “So you pick up burnt potatoes at the carvery counter out of the many that are there and you can choose from and think we are dumb ”Karina Barker said: “We ate there tonight and the roast potatoes were lush, I like mine crispy like that.“ButI didn’t, I just wouldn’t have picked them. There was another choice - don’t get the potatoes.”Johnny Higgs replied: “Yes, because that’s why you have a roast dinner. To not have roast potatoes.”Peter Emmerson-Darnell said: “That is one disgusting plate of and I use the term loosely...food!!”Laura’s original post showed the spuds nestling between what looks like mashed potato or caullower and meat, alongside a dollop of mayonnaise.After Facebookers accused her of making it up – she hit back: “The ones that came out after looked okay but they expected everyone to eat these first there was no other choice.“Please don’t insult my intelligence by thinking I would pick these over nicer ones.“Obviously the whole lot looked like this trust me I picked the least burnt ones believe it or not.“Clearly these were the potatoes they were serving even the waitress was disgusted and gave us one meal free.”A spokesman for Toby Carvery said: “All our roast potatoes are peeled, chopped and cooked fresh throughout the day.”

title: kate middleton prince george princess charlotte playdates
story: The Duchess of Cambridge said she was passing her love of the arts onto her two eldest children - with five-year-old Prince George even inspired to use charcoal from a fireplace to draw her a picture.The mum-of-three, who studied a master of arts degree in art history at St Andrews University, beamed as she chatted about to staff and students during a school visit yesterday.Kate, , admitted she loved art, saying: Its something Im loving doing with the children - papier mache - I forgot how messy it is, but its really great.She also said her son George had picked up on her love of art - already delving into his creative side.The duchess recounted how the young future king had found a piece of charcoal in a fireplace and told her: Mummy Im going to draw a picture.She explained: Thats whats so nice, you can do it from all around you.And Kate even gave a sneak peek into her fashion sense as the class learnt about dferent types of printing.As Andria Zafirakou, named as the worlds best teacher, discussed fashions, Kate laughed and added: Im desperate to go back to tie dye.Kates visit to Lavender Primary School in Enfield, North London and Alperton Community School in Brent, North West London, marked Childrens Mental Health Week - a subject close to her heart.The -year-old has previously spoken out about the importance of supporting kids mental health, encouraging them to be comfortable in their own skin.And during her visit yesterday, Kate discussed what could be achievedchildren turned off the Internet and instead got creative.Shown students artwork, the impressed mum said: This is what you can doyou dont use social media - a fantastic advert.Earlier Kate produced a treasured family photo when she joined a group of primary schoolchildren asked to take in an object that makes them happy.The picture, taken at Amber Hall in Norfolk last year, shows the Cambridges posing with their children George, Charlotte and Louis and was first released as their family Christmas card.She told pupils, as she took the photo out of her purse: This is a photograph of my family, these are my children and this is my husband, and my family makes me happy - we like playing outside together and spending lots of time together and that makes me happy.She was dressed in a green £, Eponine dress with £ LK Bennett boots for the chilly day out.Ms Zafirakou, who was awarded a million dollarsin prize money and the  Varkey Foundation Global Teacher Prize, praised the royal visit to her school.Commenting on Kates admission she does art with her children she said: So shes a very hands on mum who understands about being creative - its just brilliant and lovely to hear that and as a mother myself I know exactly what that means.She stressed how the school supports not only the pupils academic aspirations but their personal development.Our approach is that were not an exam factory type of school, we do look at the childrens well-being and prepare them for their futures and also how to look after themselves.And I dont think we would ever survivewe dont have that approach.

title: boy plays piano london st pancras station
story: The boy sat at a piano in London St Pancras station and began playing a complex tune, inducing spontaneous applause from passers by who stopped to listen.In a video of the musical performance the boy can be seen losing himself in song before standing up to face the crowd gathered around him, looking bemused.Organist Gwen Mtambirwa, who witnessed the event, said the boy was - years old at most, possibly a bit younger.She said: Certainly when he turned round and smiled at his dad he didnt look that old.Gwen posted a video of the talent to Twitter with the caption: Just occasionally some utter joy happens on the pianos at St Pancras...At St Pancras train station in North London there is always a piano which the public are welcome to play.Videos of talented musicians trying their hand on the instrument often go viral online.Gwen added: I heard him finish off another piece as I walked through to get my train, but hed jumped off and run back to his parents he ran back to the piano - so I stopped and listened - hedrew quite a crowd.Shame my phone sound wasnt great - gave me goosebumps.Other Twitter users replied to Gwens tweet to express their joy at hearing such a talented young musician.Helen Brough wrote: There are some piano players that are really quite brilliant ...it certainly changes your mood instantly.And Jeremiah Gooner said: What a talent, he can barely touch the pedals, superb.Meanwhile others commented on the unrealistic expectation for other kids to match his talent.Peter Chingaipe wrote: The guy with the kid on his shoulders took one quick look and swtly moved along. Good idea that, no need to raise ridiculous expectations on the boy at an early age.And another wrote: Poor kid. Bet his parents are a nightmare.

title: china nuclear aircraft carriers rival us sea
story: Each battleship will reportedly be equipped with electromagnetic aircraft catapults similar to those already being used by the US Navy.China currently only has one carrier in active service – the Liaoning - compared to the US which has  in operation.America also expects the biggest carrier in the world, the , tonne USS Gerald R Ford, to join its fleet sometime next year.The seafaring giant has the capacity to carry more than  aircraft and can accommodate a massive crew of more than ,.However, the SCMP reports after decades of trying to close the gap, China’s naval hardware might finally being catching up .China’s hi-tech new nuclear-powered aircraft carriers are all expected to join the navy by , said expert Wang Yunfei.But the retired PLA destroyer naval officer added only four will work at the front line.Beijing has made it clear it is keen to expand its aircraft carrier battle groups so it can defend its growing overseas interests.Construction of its next diesel-powered aircraft carrier - the Type  - has already begun.News of Chinas plans come after experts warned a war between US and Chinese forces in the South China Sea could break out later this year.Concerns are mounting the two superpowers could become embroiled in a terrying conflict in the region which could kill thousands.Malcolm Davis, a senior analyst in defence strategy at the Australian Strategic Policy Institute said: Expect greater tension in the South China Sea. China won’t back down - nor will the US.The South China Sea will remain a key flashpoint between China and the US, who are now engaged in an extended period of strategic competition.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mays deputy bravely comes out to bat for the brexit he tried to stop
story: With Theresa May on alternative arrangements in Ireland, in came her de facto deputy to defend a Brexit he fervently campaigned to prevent.The arch-Europhile sucked it up and tried to mock Labour over Sir Keir Starmer’s call to “explore” keeping free movement.He kicked back calls to delay Article .And he even agreed with arch-Eurosceptic Andrew Bridgen that it would be completely wrong to have a second referendum.But then we’re getting used to politicians these days arguing for things they privately have no desire to carry on with.Over on Labour’s bench, Shadow Foreign Secretary and Remainer Emily Thornberry popped up to urge the Government to seek a customs union with the EU.But that was largely that as ‘Lidders’ enjoyed highlighting Mr Corbyn’s gaffe last week when he opposed the Irish ‘backstop’.Ms Thornberry at least began with a bit of her customary sass as she rose to the despatch box.She remarked that Mr Lidington was often described as “effectively the Prime Minister’s deputy”.Pausing for the drum roll - she added that you don’t often hear the words “effective” and “prime minister” in the same sentence.Speaker Bercow was observed laughing heartily in his chair.

title: meghan markle news dad thomas devastation olive branch
story: The Duchess of Sussex gave Thomas Markle an olive branch after telling him: I have one father - but incredibly he responded by shamelessly asking for a photo shoot with her.Five close friends told People magazine that Meghan had been left absolutely devastated by her dads response.It comes after a turbulent  months for Meghan since her relationship with Prince Harry was revealed, with her family repeatedly cashing in on her rising profile.Meghans family drama has seen Thomas interviewed on national television, calling his daughter controlling while her half-sister Samantha Markle regularly takes to social media to criticise her.But speaking anonymously, the pals revealed the -year-old had tried to reach out to her -year-old dad after he pulled out of walking her down the aisle and gave a string of interviews with the press.In the letter, the pregnant duchess reportedly wrote: I have one father. Please stop victimizing me through the media.A pal said: After she and Harry got back from honeymoon, Meg sat down and wrote Thomas a long letter.She told him she loved him, she was heartbroken and wanted to put everything behind them.She forgave him for everything that had happened previously and just wanted to repair their relationship.Meg asked him to stop victimising her through the media and talk to her, not them.He replied in a very long letter, saying he loved her and wanted to make amends.But he finished the letter with the suggestion that the two of them should pose for a picture or stage a picture to show the world theyd made up.She was absolutely devastated.It was posing for pictures that had started this mess, and now he wanted to do the same thing with her She just couldnt believe it so she didnt reply.He has her number, she hasnt changed it. But hes never called or texted, despite what he says.The friends, said to be in Meghans inner circle, told the publication that the former actress had even called her dad on the morning of her wedding, saying: I think she will always feel genuinely devastated by what he has done.It come after Thomas Markle claimed he had not had any contact with Meghan since she married Prince Harry last May.He was left embarrassed after it emerged he had staged photographs with paparazzi in the lead up to the Royal Wedding.Friends said Meghan had asked her dad about the story before it was released, with the recluse swearing up and down it wasnt true.They said: The next day, the pictures come out.Thomas last year claimed he feared he had been ghosted by Meghan - begging her to text him.But Meghans friends said she had been a rock for everyone in her family, saying: The fact that this could be flipped around, that she was acting out or not caring for him, is preposterous.Sticking up for Meghan, the group of friends also hit out at claims she was dficult -  as well as speculation she had clashed with sister-in-law Kate Middleton.They said: She is the same person though everything around her has changed.There is nothing behind the feud with Kate. Its completely untrue.Pals also hit back at the abuse that the -year-old had faced since marrying Prince Harry - with it this week revealed that Kensington Palace were having to spend hours moderating and deleting abusive comments.Friends said: We want to stand up against the global bullying were seeing .Kensington Palace declined to comment.

title: no deal brexit would be fault of stubborn eurocrats playing hardball top brexiteer storms
story: Chris Grayling launched a barnstorming attack on Brussels sayingwe left without a deal they would be entirely to blame, and not us.Just hours before it was revealed that Theresa May will dash to Brussels this week for talks with the EU over her deal, he said that Britain was doing all it could to try and reach agreement.But he warned in an interview with The Daily :  If they are not willing to compromise,theyre not willing to work with us to find common ground - it will be down to themthere is no deal.And he added: We want to work with the EU to reach a deal butthey are not prepared to do that - they will have to take responsibility that we are heading towards a no-deal exit.The EU have repeatedly insisted that they wont budge on the Irish border - saying the deal is done and dusted.He insisted Mrs May would be tough in the upcoming talks, but that there would be no chance of Article  being delayed at all.Ive been in every Cabinet meeting and theres been no conversation about delaying post-March , he said.We are not delaying Article .And Mr Grayling also slapped down scaremongering reports of food shortages after we leave the EU by saying: No, Im not stockpiling.Trade would continue to flow freely after we leave no matter what happens, we insisted.So its not a case that once we leave the EU that food supplies will suddenly dry up.His comments were echoed today by ex-Brexit boss Dominic Raab.In an interview with ConservativeHome this morning he said that: It will be important for people to see thatthe EU remain stubbornly intransigent, they are the ones courting the WTO exit.People understand that we need to leave on th March. Whether they voted Leave or Remain, the one thing you hear is get this thing done and dusted.Leaving without a deal wouldnt be the end of the world, but it wouldnt be a walk in the park, he said, which is also the view of Roberto Azevedo, the Director of the World Trade Organisation.Mr Raab even hinted that Britain could be SAFER after Brexit - because well be able to refuse entry to anyone that border officials are worried about.Britain is due to leave the EU on March  no matter what happens, but the PM has promised to go back and ask for changes to the hated Northern Irish backstop.Mrs May is still clinging to her deal, but accepts that MPs dont want it in its current form.She will come up with the plan to take to Brussels later this week which involves major changes to the Northern Ireland border.

title: brexit secret high tech irish border
story: Officials from DexEU have been quietly working on the blueprint – drawn up by Japanese firm Fujitsu – for  months.But, it has been rapidly dusted down in the last week after MPs voted to replace the current Irish backstop with a dferent one that could involve “alternative arrangements”.An  page briefing on the explosive Futitsu plan has been leaked to The Sun.Named the ‘Drive Through Border Concept’, it ensures there is no need for any physical checks on the border or hard infrastructure.Instead, a tracking system monitors vehicles on designated routes as they cross from Northern Ireland to the Republic via GPS as well as number plate recognition cameras.Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay is studying the plan closely.It has also been circulated among a working group of senior Tory Leavers and Remainers who have come together to propose a new backstop based on stand-off customs checks, dubbed the Malthouse Compromise.EU critics of the alternative arrangements to change the backstop have claimed the technology doesn’t yet exist to police the border and are years away.But The Sun’s revelation today heaps more pressure on PM Theresa May to agree to push the border plan during talks in Brussels tomorrow.The Sun has also learned that the working group has also been briefed on a goods tracking system in Africa that has used the same technology for the last  months.Designed to ward off bandits and hijackers, the Regional Electronic Cargo Tracking System operates across borders between Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda.A Tory minister involved in the talks told The Sun: “Given that we can land a probe the size of a fridge on Mars, it can’t be beyond us to devise an imperceptible system for a  mile border”.Fujitsu have promised DexEU that proof of concept trials on the border with  hauliers testing their system will be ready by March .Marked ‘Restricted – Commercial in Confidence’, the document also reveals the plan allowsProof of concept ready for a trial by March ,  hauliers to test itThe only infrastructure needed to run the system are number plate recognition cameras on approach roads to the border itself.But that could anger nationalists who will say it break Mrs May’s promise of no infrastructure at all.The Fujitsu system could also be rejected by the Northern Irish, who have a deep dislike of state surveillance that dates back to the Troubles era.A DExEU spokesperson said: Throughout this process the Government has explored options with firms and experts for proposals to solve the issue of the Irish border.As the Political Declaration makes clear, the UK and the EU have committed to exploring what alternative arrangements to the backstop might look like. We are also clear that those solutions can not include new border infrastructures.”THE French last night told Transport Secretary Chris Grayling he was not welcome at Calais after he announced plans to ert ferries from the port under a no deal Brexit.The head of the French port Jean-Marc Puissesseau said he was never welcome toto the port as he accused Mr Grayling of being “completely disrespectful” for failing to forewarn the French about his contingency plans.The Sun revealed in October that Mr Grayling had drawn up plans to lease space on ferries so the Government can redirect them to Rotterdam and Belgian ports in case of logjams at Calais.Mr Puissesseau said the Transport Secretary gave no warning about the proposals - despite attending a meeting with port officials who insisted they could cope with extra customs checks that would be neededBritain crashes out of the EU without a deal.The French port chief told the : “Mr Grayling came to us in November and asked uswe would be ready. We told him ‘yes’, though we did not know as much as we know today. He did not tell us that he wanted to reduce the activity [at Calais].“It is not fair at all, it is completely disrespectful. I don’t want to see him again.”Mr Puissesseau added that Calais had injected fresh cash for a new traffic light system that will help combat logjams under a no deal Brexit.Green will be for lorries that have the correct paperwork, amber for those who are not sure and red for vehicles with no paperwork.He joked that Mr Grayling was so unpopular that he would also have to pass throught the traffic light systemhe did attempt to visit Calais.Mr Puissesseau said: “I have heard he is ‘failing Grayling’...He will have to have a declarationhe comes to Calais. He will have to go through the orange lane.”The anti-Brexit Best for Britain group last night said the move effectively meant Mr Grayling was “banned” from Calais.One of its supporters and Labour MP Virendra Sharma said: “Surely this is peak Chris Grayling - only this time he’s gone international.“All he needs to do now is release a statement blaming everyone  and his predictable path of chaos will be complete.”A spokesman from the Department for Transport said: “While the Transport Secretary strongly supports work across Government with the EU to ensure a deal is reached, he will also continue to lead the DfT to ensure all contingencies are prepared for concerning Brexit.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit latest eu brussels david davis theresa may
story: The ex-Brexit secretary urged the PM to hold firm as he was still confident that a deal can be done and the bloc had history of getting things done at the last moment.Theres just over  days to go until we leave the EU on March , with or without a deal.Mr Davis calmed fears when he wrote in the Dailythis morning: The EU has a history of making deals at the eleventh hour. They will always let negotiations go to the wire.Greece was denied a bailout at first but then the EU gave in and handed it three, he pointed out.The Brexiteer lashed out at the confrontational approach of the bloc and said the bloc should offer us a full free trade agreement like it has with other states like Canada and New Zealand.And he urged: This is the time for Government and Parliament to hold their nerve.There is no case whatsoever for an Article  extension. Instead, we need to insist on a deal that is mutually beneficial - not punitive - and that can be shown to work for everyone.DUP leader Arlene Foster echoed his words today as Mrs May visited Northern Ireland to talk to businesses and leaders about how to solve the problem of the Irish border.She said after talks with the PM that she should stand strong in her efforts to try and get the deal changed.It is welcome that the Prime Minister is travelling to Brussels to seek changes but she must stand strong and by the commitments she made to the House of Commons, she said.MPs have demanded she goes back to Brussels to rip out the hated border backstop and replace it with something .So far the EU have stood firm and insisted they cant re-open the agreement.German Chancellor Angela Merkel is set to press the Irish to compromise on high tech solutions to the Irish border, it was revealed today.Shes spearheading efforts to try and get a deal over the line by getting everyone to come together.The Irish have dismissed any solutions so far, saying they dont exist or just dont work.But a source in Berlin told The Times that Mrs Merkel was very hopeful that the backstop could be solved with a combination of new technology and a sophisticated customs scheme.She is waiting for London to come forward with concrete proposals about how it would work,” the source said.Dublin will come under a lot of pressure over the coming weeks to work constructively with London.”Leo Varadkar, the Irish prime minister, has been called to Brussels today for talks with the bloc ahead of the PM flying out there tomorrow.Hes seeking aid from the EU to get Ireland ready for No Deal.Yesterday the bloc warned that Ireland faced a choice between keeping the border open to preserve the peace, and facing the prospect of a new border in the Irish sea which would see it ided from the rest of the bloc.He said this morning there was a growing desire in the bloc to do more to stop a No Deal from happening.

title: greg hands eu customs union free trade agreement brexit
story: We’ve heard about all the dficulties leaving the EU presents, but we need a chance to learn more about the opportunities.Ninety per cent of global economic growth will come from outside the EU in the years ahead. Brexit allows us to look beyond the shores of the EU and to agree free trade deals with the US and countries like Canada and Japan through the Trans Pacic Partnership.I was one of the trade ministers until I resigned over Heathrow Airport expansion last summer. As Minister for Trade Policy, it was my job, working with Trade Secretary Liam Fox, to design Britain’s free trading future outside of the EU.And today, I have joined my colleague, David Davis, and lawyers, Shanker Singham and Barney Reynolds, to present a comprehensive UK-EU Free Trade Agreement- the most advanced free trade agreement ever developed. It shows how we can make the most of our post-Brexit future.Our FTA creates a level playing field in competition policy and state aid, so that UK and EU firms aren’t given unfair advantages over each other by their respective governments.It protects workers’ rights, ensures that financial services like banking and insurance can operate freely and it will allow us to help the developed world as we will be able to y our tarfs on their exports, helping them to develop their economies.We based it on existing arrangements that the EU has already agreed including with Canada and Japan, so we know the EU will want to agree a text similar to this one.Many people say that the EU takes many years to negotiate an FTA and cite the seven years it took to negotiate the CETA deal with Canada. This has often taken a long time because of long and protracted rows about tarfs and the level they should be set at.But the UK is in the unique position of having identical tarfs and regulations to the EU to begin with. So it shouldn’t take very long andwe’re conducting trade negotiations quickly with other countries around the world, it will put pressure on the EU to agree a deal quickly.Staying in the EU customs union would be the worst of all options. We would be unable to set our own trade and development policy and we wouldn’t have a say – we would have to defer to Brussels on it all.When it comes to trade talks,you don’t have a seat at the table, you’re probably on the menu!The EU would be negotiating trade deals on the UK’s behalf, but we would have no say. That is what leaving the EU but staying in its customs union would mean. We would be irrelevant in trade policy terms to the rest of the world and it would come as no surprise to mewe ended up at the back of everyone’s queues.The only way to overcome the challenges of leaving the EU, and to take advantage of the opportunities at the same time, is through a comprehensive and advanced FTA with the EU. This would allow us to negotiate comprehensive FTAs with others, and to once again be a force to be reckoned with at the World Trade Organisation.We need a strong and self-confident Britain on the world stage, making trade agreements that benefit British workers and consumers.Today’s publication of a draft but detailed Free Trade Agreement allows us to do exactly that.

title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . story: NewsBoozed-up lads stranded for SIX hours after Uber to Narnia gets stuck in snowRobbie Muir and Shaun Thornton shared their drink-fuelled adventure with an Uber driver in towShareByJack AitchisonKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video brazen-lads-go-wild-uber-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pair of boozed-up lads found themselves stuck in the snowy Highlands for six hours with their Glasgow taxi driver.Robbie Muir and Shaun Thornton had just enjoyed a night out in Glasgow when, despite the treacherous conditions, they decided to grab an Uber ride to a pals cottage in Aberfeldy for pound.But the joyous, drunken trip turned into misery for the pair - and their driver - when they ended up stuck in the snow and believing the chances of dying are pretty high.Sharing the madcap experience on Facebook , which has now gone viral, Robbie wanted to let friends know that he was safe after being AWOL with no phone signal, the Daily Record reports. title: emiliano salas shipwreck hunter solved
story: NewsEmiliano Salas shipwreck hunter has solved some of the worlds greatest maritime mysteriesIn his  year career David Mearns has found  wrecks lost on ocean floors for decades and even centuriesShareByMatt Roper:,  FEB NewsDavid Mearns is the worlds leading shipwreck finder "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email He has been the face of the privately-funded search for the plane was carrying Argentine footballer Emiliano Sala . And within just a few hours David Mearns managed to track down the missing Piper Malibu on Sunday, which was on its way to Cardf when it disappeared last month.Sala’s family appealed to the marine scientist after an official search for the aircraft was stood down and an online crowdfunding campaign to fund it raised more than pound,. But those who know David were not remotely surprised the man known as The Shipwreck Hunter was able to locate the plane so quickly. The expert, who was born in the US but is now a British citizen living in Sussex, has helped solve some of history’s greatest maritime mysteries.   He has lead searches for shipwrecks that have been at the bottom of the sea of decades, even centuries, making  major historical discoveries over the last  years. Using sonar technology and remote-controlled submarines, his expeditions have also set records for finding wrecks at extreme depths - and even helped solve crimes that would have remained forever undetected. But despite his successes he still dreams of finding one wreck which has eluded him - Sir Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance, which crashed into ice and sank off Antartica in .  He told the Times in : “If I could cap it all off with Endurance, I would be a happy, happy man because it is the ultimate shipwreck search in terms of dficulty and challenge.“Harder than Titanic. Finding a deep-water shipwreck in the Weddell Sea when it is covered in ice, you are not going to get any harder than that.” Most of David’s finds, though, have been the result of exceptionally hard work - often years of research, months at sea and millions of pounds. And with three Guinness World Records for underwater discoveries, including one for the deepest shipwreck ever found - the German blockade runner Rio Grande, which was discovered at a depth of ,ft - he is now regarded as the man to turn to when it comes to retrieving from the ocean floor. One of the -year-old’s most famous discoveries was the HMS Hood, one of Britain’s greatest battleships, which was sunk by the German navy’s Bismark in May .  There were just three survivors among the , on board, their lives saved by an air bubble that pushed them back to the surface. Among them was Ted Briggs, who David had met and sought consent from before setting out for a Channel  documentary to find the ship in . He eventually found the wreck at a depth of , ft at the bottom of the Denmark Strait, where he got another Guinness World Record for the deepest live broadcast on the internet, with live footage of the HMS Hood being streamed around the world. But he later recalled how there was none of the usual shouts of excitement when the ship was finally discovered. He said: “There were no whoops or joy of back-slaps. It was such an emotional and sad moment for me. I didn’t feel like celebrating in any way.”  When a plaque was placed on the wreck, now a recognised war grave, he made sure that it was Ted Briggs’ hands in control of an underwater robot when it wasreleased onto the wreck. He remembered: “For Ted personally, it allowed him a chance to say goodbye to his shipmates, to remove from his shoulders the guilt that he had felt his whole le as one of only three who survived. “In a sense, he laid a ghost to rest. It was something that I’ll never ever forget - a very proud moment for everybody that we witnessed that.” Other sunken warships he has found with his company Blue Water Recoveries include the HMAS Sydney, an Australian navy battle cruiser sunk by the Germans off Australias west coast in November , killing . It was the the country’s greatest maritime mystery for  years until he found the ship in . David also found the hospital ship Centaur, which was torpedoed off Queensland by a Japanese submarine in , for which he was awarded an honorary Medal of the Order of Australia.  He was also part of a team in  led by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, which located the wreckage of the Japanese battleship Msashi in the Sibuyan Sea. And in  he found a wreck he believes to be the SS Athenia, the first ship sunk in the Second World War at a cost of  lives when German U-boat commander Fritz Julius Lemp torpedoed the transatlantic liner – believing it was a warship – just hours after Britain had declared war on the Nazis. Describing his care with such wrecks, where many lives were lost, he said: “The sanctity of those grave sites and whoever has been lost is very important. “They are major unmarked grave sites, with no head stones to show who has been lost there, and that why we take this effort andto put plaques on the wreck, to leave a marker that those people haven’t been forgotten.” David, who trained as a marine biologist, began his career as a search and recovery contractor for the US Navy.  But his le changed forever when he was tasked with finding MV Lucona, a cargo ship which was blown up in the Indian Ocean in  at the cost of six lives. After finding the ship at ,ft, he found it had been blown apart by a bomb for an insurance fraud by Austrian businessman Udo Proksch, who was subsequently convicted in  of murdering six of his crew. He went on to defy the odds by finding dozens of other lost vessels, many of which had been shrouded in mystery for decades, boasting a  per cent success rate. Describing the months he often spends at sea searching for wrecks, he says: “Being on the water is great, I love being out there.  You see some days when it’s call, and days when it’s really mountainous seas. You’re working every minute of every hour when you’re awake.” He says that the discovery he’s most proud of was the SMAS Sydney, which nobody thought would ever be found. He said: “It’s not exaggerating to say that all of Australia was following that search. We had the worst luck, everything went wrong. Equipment failures, bad weather, the ship broke down…” He said he felt “pure exhilaration” when it showed up on his sonar.   In March , David announced the discovery of Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gaza’s Esmerelda, which sunk in . It is believed to be the earliest ship from Europe’s Age of Discovery ever to be found and excavated. Despite his extraordinary career, David says he will only be satisfied when when he finds three elusive wrecks. One is the legendary Endurance, but he won’t reveal the other two as shipwreck hunting is a competitive business. He says: “There’s three of them, and I haven’t given up on them. They leave this tortured feeling that you have, of unfinished business.”
