story: A total of .% of investors approved the plan on Wednesday at a general meeting in Edinburgh.The Government, which still owns % of RBS, did not vote on the resolution.The lenderrsquos special resolution sought permission to make off-market share purchases from the Treasury through a ldquodirected buy-back scheme.Under the scheme,which will need to be approved by the Treasury and the Bank of England, RBS will be able to buy back up to .% of the Governmentrsquos stake in any one year.However, one shareholder at the meeting described the plan as ldquoabhorrent, arguing that RBS should be holding back the cash to pay compensation for potentially huge legal settlements.He also accused the bank of ldquorunning scared from a potential general election and resultant Labour government, which would seek to nationalise the bank.But chairman Howard Davies said: ldquoThis is something that the board has carefully considered. The bank has a sufficiently strong capital position. Theywill have to speak for themselves.RBS has been majority taxpayer owned since , when it received a pound billion bailout at the height of the financial crisis.The Treasury plans to sell its stake by , but is expected to lose billions in the process.RBS was bailed out at p per share in , but its stock is trading at around p today.The shares bought from the Government are expected to be cancelled, which would increase the value of the bankrsquos outstanding shares.RBS has been exploring a share buy-back programme since last year when it declared its first idend in a decade in order to bring the public holding to less than % by the end of the current parliament.In the Autumn Budget, Chancellor Philip Hammond said the Government intends exit its ownership of the bank by .RBS said the buy-back could take place aspart of a placement by the Treasury at a price determined through an open-market book-building process.Or it could happen via a bilateral deal whereby the bank buys a certain number of shares at the relevant market price agreed with Treasury, independent of any larger placement of shares by the Government.The final method under consideration would be a trading programme in which a broker is nominated to oversee the daily purchase of a certain percentage of shares at the market price.Following shareholder approval for the share buy-back programme, a Treasury spokesman said:ldquoThe Government should not be in the business of owning banks, which is why wersquore committed to ing RBS back to private ownership.ldquoBut we will only sell RBS shares when it represents value for money to do so. Todayrsquos vote does not commit us to sell shares in any one way and we keep all options open.RBS is due to publish full-year results on February .

title: glasgow-airport-rail-link-to-be-ditched-for-rapid-shuttle-pod-to-paisley
story: A Personal Rapid Transit shuttle pod between Glasgow Airport and Paisley Gilmour Street has emerged as the likely alternative to a full tram-train rail link.Following a meeting between Glasgow and Renfrewshire council leaders, the Transport Secretary and Glasgow Airport yesterday, it has been agreed to work on a business case for the Personal Rapid Transit system.It would see passengers board the pods like ones used at Heathrow Airport to take them to the station at Paisley where they would catch existing services to Glasgow and where.AYE OR NAW, MICHAEL :Our message to transport secretary amid fresh fears over airport rail linkThe final choice will be between the tram-train option and the Personal Rapid Transit pod.It is, however, likely that the rapid transit option will be the preferred one and the option taken forward.The tram-train link hit problems following a study that said it would impact negatively on other services in the West of Scotland and on Central Station which is at capacity.The Evening Times message to the transport secretary earlier this monthSusan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoImproved connectivity to Glasgow Airport is a key priority. However, the advice from officers and consultants is that signicant questions remain about the deliverability of the current tram-train option, particularly in relation to capacity at Central Station.ldquoAs a result, the Executive Steering Group has agreed additional work should be done to establish an alternative Outline Business Case for a Personal Rapid Transitoption.ldquoThis work was not advanced by the previous City Deal Cabinet, but it is now crucial in order to allow us to make a fully-informed choice about which of the options in front of us should be progressed.:Glasgow Airport rail link saga has dragged on for far too longldquoI remain committed to a solution that delivers improved public transport connectivity to Glasgow Airport - but I am determined it should also provide value for money for the city, and deliver the widest possible inclusive economic benefits.ldquoIrsquom confident we have made signicant progress towards that outcome today.Glasgow Airport said congestion on the M means action is needed and ldquodoing nothing is not an option.Mark Johnston, managing director at Glasgow Airport, said: ldquoWe were informed that, due to issues around rail capacity, the project partners are developing an alternative option.: Half a million to go on addressing airport rail link fearsldquoThis will be evaluated and we will, of course, work with the partners to promote the delivery of an effective solution within the agreed timescale.It has been understood that transport officials were not keen on progressing the tram-train link from Glasgow Central to the airport.Michael Matheson, Transport Secretary, said: ldquoItrsquos crucial that improving access to Glasgow Airport is balanced with the needs of the regionrsquos existing transport network.ldquoThe Personal Rapid Transit system option potentially meets this aim, and I look forward to seeing the revised business case once itrsquos completed.

title: nicola-sturgeon-too-soon-to-make-informed-decision-on-independence
story: The First Minister also said she had yet to make up her own mind about a fresh vote.In an interview on American TV, she said she would wait for a Brexit conclusion, and only then take a decision ldquobased on a calm consideration of whats in Scotlands best interests.:Nicola Sturgeon in US: Its clearer Scotlands national interests are not served by WestminsterHinting at a long process, she told PBS NewsHour that voters had a right to ldquoas much information as possible about an independent Scotlandrsquos relationship with the UK and EU.She did not want an ldquouninformed decision about a big change, as with Brexit.The cautious language will disappoint the gung-ho elements of the Yes movement, including some past and present SNP MPs, who have been agitating for a referendum this year.Ms Sturgeonhas been urged to capitaliseon the "chaos" at Westminster.Herpreference for"calm consideration"reflects the complications ofBrexit, which could change Scotlandrsquos options on the economy and the currency.Theresa May also continues to withhold referendum powers from Holyrood, making it unlikely that a referendum can be held before the next Holyrood election in .Ms Sturgeon is in the US and Canada this week to promote Scottish interests.In a speech to the Georgetown Institute on Monday, she repeated her commitment to give an update on the timing of another independence referendum in a ldquofew weeks.But in her PBS interview, the First Minister suggested this may not be the call to arms many of her supporters would like.She said the Brexit vote and the way Scotland had been ignored by London in the aftermath showed ldquocircumstances have changed materially since , the trigger set down in the SNP manesto of  for Holyrood having the right to call another referendum.She said: ldquoWhen the time is right for Scotland to look again at the question of independence, I think, would be the right thing to allow it to do.But asked when she thought the time would be right, she replied: ldquoWell, I think we have to allow the [Brexit] process that is currently underway to reach some conclusion. What that conclusion will be remains to be seen.ldquoAnd then take a decision based on a calm consideration of whats in Scotlands best interests. And thats what I would do.ldquoSo Im not going to say right now what I think the best timing would be.Pressed on why she didnt go ahead with a referendum given her complaints about Scotland being ignored during Brexit, Ms Sturgeon said voters didnrsquot have enough facts to decide.She said: ldquoClearly,people in Scotland are being asked, given the opportunity to look again at the independence question, they have a right to have as much information as possible about what -Scotland chooses to be independent - what our relationships will be with the rest of the UK and with Europe.ldquoAnd some of the answers to those questions inevitably depend on the Brexit outcome to some extent. And, therefore, I think its in the interest of allowing an informed decision to be taken about independence that we allow some of that clarity to emerge.:Nicola Sturgeon to use US speech to outline possible timing of indyrefldquoBrexit is a good example of what happens when people take, in some respects, an uninformed decision about a big change. And when people, as I believe they will in due course, opt for Scotland to be an independent country, that should be on the basis of a genuinely informed decision about all of the implications and consequences.Ms Sturgeon first promised a ldquoprecise timescale on another vote in June , after SNP losses in the general election derailed her plan for a Brexit-related referendum.The update was due in October but has been repeatedly put off because of the rolling confusion and delays over Brexit at Westminster.The hold-ups on Indyref have been criticised by SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeil, and former FM Alex Salmond has questionedthe ldquocaledonian leboat will ever launch.The SNP is currently refreshing its economic case for independence through Andrew Wilsonrsquos Growth Commission, but Brexit would add a new layer of complications.For instance, in , the SNP argued an independent Scotland could continue to use the pound as part of a currency union with the rest of the UK.Howeverthe UK were outside the EU, it is highly unlikely that Brussels would allow an independent Scotland to join the EU while also using the currency of a non-EU state.

title: revealed-the-scottish-hmv-stores-set-for-closure
story: Fopp on Byres Road in Glasgowrsquos west end is one of three stores in Scotland which will close after HMV was acquired from administrators by Canadian firm Sunrise Records and Entertainment.The HMV stores in Ayr and Braehead are also among the  stores which have been earmarked for closure. Administrators at KMPG said the closures will result in  job losses.Sunrise, which has been owned by Doug Putman since , has acquired  HMV stores out of administration, securing nearly , jobs in the process.Tenstores in Scotland have been saved, including eight outlets trading as HMV and just two as Fopp ndash the Union Street branch in Glasgow and the Fopp outlet on Edinburghrsquos Rose Street. The HMV stores to have survived are in Aberdeen, Dundee, East Kilbride, Inverness, Livingston, Stirling, Glasgowrsquos Argyle Street and Edinburghrsquos Ocean Terminal shopping centre.Thank you for all of your kind words on Twitter over the past few weeks, sorry we have been a bit quiet.Unfortunately weve had to say goodbye to some amazing people today. Thank you for your dedication  passion over the years. We will miss you. pic OxNBTxSFThe deal marks the second time HMV has emerged from administration, with previous owner Hilco Capital snapping it up following its first failure in .

title: print-queen-orla-kiely-reflects-on-a-life-in-colour-at-new-exhibition
story: If you have not heard of Orla Kiely, you will almost certainly recognise her work, with her iconic prints appearing on products from handbags and dresses to wallpaper, tea towels and bath mats.The Irish designerrsquos work spans  years and now fashion and design enthusiasts can look back at some of her finest creations in a new exhibition launching in Edinburgh.Read More Galleries: Visual Arts picks of Orla Kiely: A Le in Pattern opens at Dovecot Studios on Thursday and offers visitors an insight into her methods and concepts, with sketches, mood boards, and samples on display.Celia Joicey, director of Dovecot, said: ldquoDovecot Studios is bringing Orla Kiely A Le in Pattern to Scotland to highlight the contagious popularity of a brand that has captured the zeitgeist for pattern and colour in st century design.ldquoAs a tapestry studio, textiles are a way of le at Dovecot and we look forward to exploring the importance of textile to Orla Kiely as a medium for self-expression and the foundation of a global business.Read moreDesign hub plans to open arts and crafts base in DundeeInspired by the s and a love of Irish and Scandinavian architecture, Kielyrsquos designs have grown from humble beginnings in the s to become a global phenomenon, attracting fans such as the Duchess of Cambridge, Keira Knightley and Scarlett Johansson.The exhibition features many personal items depicting how Kielyrsquos le has shaped her designs along the way.As the designer herself put it: ldquoPattern is not a trend for me. Pattern is in me. It is my le.Read moreVA Dundee scoops design magazine award for best new buildingVisit www.dovecotstudios for tickets and information.

title: club-scheme-helps-fans-find-fitness
story: But now a group supporters devotion to their clubs has also delivered a huge benefit to their personal lives by helping them get fitter and shrink unhealthy waistlines.A project which aimed to improve the health of male football fans at  European clubs has resulted in "signicant" improvements in participants weight and diet, according to research.The European Fans in Trainingprogramme, based on a course devised by a team at the University of Glasgow, was also found to have led to improvements in the mens sense of well-being and self-esteem.The EU-funded scheme involved more than , men between the ages of  and  who are fans of football clubs in England, the Netherlands, Norway and Portugal.:Scots who cant cook basic meals fuel obesity crisisArsenal, Manchester City, PSV Eindhoven, Rosenborg and FC Porto were among the clubs involved in the programme, which was based on a model developed in Scotland.Arsenal were one of the clubs to take part ...During the EuroFIT programme, fans attended weekly -minute sessions with community coaches at club facilities over  weeks, with the aim of increasing their levels of physical activity and improving their diet.A pocket-worn device developed for the programme allowed monitoring of theof time spent sitting and the number of daily steps participants were doing, while an app encouraged social support between sessions.In a research trial, participants were split into two groups - the first joining the EuroFIT programme immediately, and the second being placed on a -month waiting list.The results found that the EuroFIT fans enjoyed improvements in both their general fitness and their lestyleAfter a year, men who took part in EuroFIT were doing on average  steps a day more active than the comparison group.The men had also improved their diet by eating more fruit and vegetables, less fat and less sugar and had increased their well-being and vitality.:Scots firms to unveil  radical ways tech will help our lives#However, attempts to reduce theof time spent sitting were unsuccessful.The research papers concluded there were "signicant improvements in diet, weight, well-being, self-esteem, vitality, and biomarkers of cardiometabolic health in favour of the intervention group", although not in their quality of le.EuroFIT was built on the experience of the Football Fans in Trainingprogramme for overweight and obese men, which was developed and evaluated by researchers led by the University of Glasgow.It is delivered in Scotland by the Scottish Professional Football League Trust and has been adapted for use in Canada and Australia.... Manchester City were anotherProfessor Sally Wyke, the programmes principal investigator and an interdisciplinary professor of health and well-being at Glasgow University, said:"The results of our randomised control trial of EuroFIT support the findings of the earlier FFIT study."Gender-sensitised lestyle programmes delivered in professional football clubs show great promise in Europe and could play an important public health role in engaging under-served men."The English clubs involved were Arsenal, Everton, Newcastle United, Manchester City and Stoke City.:Blindness-causing condition on the rise in Fe amid obesity epidemic#The other clubs taking part were ADO Den Haag, FC Groningen, PSV Eindhoven, Vitesse, Rosenborg, Stromsgodset, Valerenga, Benfica, FC Porto and Sporting CP.The European Healthy Stadia Network will be responsible for the rollout of EuroFIT across Europe.Last year, former Premier League Champions Leicester City and Championship side Blackburn Rovers also signed up to the programme.Barrie Shaw, Leicester City Fan and EuroFIT participant, said ldquoThe sessions have really helped, I have been able to incorporate simple lestyle changes into my everyday routine. EuroFIT has improved my physical fitness and I have since joined the Community Trustrsquos walking football team.Blackburns Programme leader, Ilyas Patel, said: "They want to keep their healthy lestyle and whilst it isnt specically a weight loss programme, we saw everyone lose weight."He added that on average his group lost an .kg in weight, along with cm of their waist measurements.Matthew Philpott, the networks executive director, said: "We are hugely excited about the rollout of EuroFIT as we now know this intervention is effective across dferent European countries."We are working with our partners at UEFA to promote this evidence-based lestyle programme to European football and are already planning delivery of the programme in a number of new territories this spring, with the aim of having EuroFIT embedded across European football over the next five years."The study has been published in the journal PLOS Medicine.

title: herald-diary-sheet-music-no-its-pretty-good
story: TALES from bus stops have always fascinated us. Says reader Angela Morgan: "I was at a bus stop in Edinburgh where a refined lady in the queue in conversation with a friend said, Oh yes, shersquos still very sharp. Second refined lady replied, Yes ndash shersquos as sharp as a button. Cue much sage nodding from both."Alarming timesTHE death of Liam Kane, The Heralds former managing director who led the companys buy-out from Lonrho  years ago, reminds us that Liam disliked staying in his management office and was often seen strolling through all departments. He was once in the caseroom, in the Mitchell Street office, where the pages of the paper were made up when the fire alarm rang. He thought he would show leadership by going out the nearest fire exit which took him down a flight of iron stairs outside the building into a small courtyard from which there was only one door.He had no idea where he was, but charged through the unmarked door ndash which turnout to be the fire exit of Sammy Dows pub in Mitchell Street. His sudden entrance startled many of The Heralds printers drinking there who used the fire exit as a regular thoroughfare throughout their sht.Milking itA SIGN of the times as Maggie Cuddihy in Leith overhears a mother in the local supermarket tell her four-year-old: "ldquoYes, I will make you chocolate milk when we get home. Do you want goat or almond Picture thisSAD news that the Fopp record store on Glasgows Byres Road is to close. We remember when former Fopp boss Peter Ellen was at a reception at Holyrood Palace where he was introduced to Prince Philip, who asked what he did. "I run music stores," said Peter, before a puzzled Philip barked: "Sheet music, is it " Peter successfully fought the urge to reply: "No, for the most part its pretty good."The other Fopp store in Glasgow, in Union Street, once had a vending machine outside the front door to sell CDs round the clock. It didnt work out. The machines mechanism was frequently clogged with photocopies of fivers, drawings of fivers, vouchers from other stores, and once a postcard from Ibiza.TransportedA READERS suggestion of coffee shops at cemeteries which could be named Creme de la Crem reminds Gordon Casely: "In the days when Glasgow Museum of Transport resided in Albert Drive, early-comers to funerals next door at St Ninianrsquos Episcopal Church used to wander into the museum, either gawping at the trams, or adjourning to the coffee shop. Museum curator, the late Dr Tony Browning, wasnrsquot put off in the slightest. As he said, It all goes to improve visitor figures."Heat is onYES, we should take climate change seriously, but a reader looking at the artists impression in The Herald yesterday of what a renovated Broomielaw in Glasgow could look like noticed that the picture included a bikini-clad woman paddle-boarding on the Clyde in the city centre. "Well,thats what global warming is going to bring, Im all for it," he says.Thats a dateGROWING old, continued. Forgetting things comes with the ageing process, but reader Robert Sutherland liked the modern take on it when he asked an ageing American friend for a date in US history, and he paused for a moment before replying: "I know this, but itrsquos up in the iCloud and Irsquove forgotten my password.HuntedAMERICAN stand-up Reginald D Hunter, one of the more thoughtful performers around, is appearing at Glasgows Kings Theatre next month. He was once interviewed by a Herald features writer before appearing at the Edinburgh Festival. She asked him about the most stupid thing he had ever done. His reply  "This interview." She included it in his reply in the feature.

title: aberdeen-scientists-to-pioneer-safety-tests-for-household-chemicals-harming-female-fertility
story: The five-year study at Aberdeen University will examine how chemicals known as endocrine disruptors affect a womans reproductive health, and help to develop tests that are reliable enough to be used by regulatory bodies.Endocrine disruptors are chemicals known to interfere with the bodys hormone systems. They have been linked to tumours and birth defects, and there is mounting evidence that they reduce both male and female fertility - both of which appear to be in decline.Read more: Scots couples invited to take part in promising trial for male contraceptive gelEndocrine disrupting compounds are found in a range of substances including air fresheners, cosmetics, plastics, pesticides and food additives, but it is unclear at what dose they begin to cause problems.Professor Paul Fowler, Director of the Institute of Medical Sciences at the University of Aberdeen, said: ldquoWe already know that endocrine disruptors can affect fertility, brain development and many other aspects of health."However, at the moment we do not have good tests to work out whether certain chemicals that require regulation, such food additives, plastic food containers, pesticides and biocides might disturb the endocrine system in people, especially women, thereby affecting their health and fertility.Read more: Four in  men in Scotland have fertility problemThe Aberdeen study is one of eight across Europe and the US under the umbrella of FREIA .Others will examine links between endocrine disruptors and issues such as metabolism and thyroid .The euro millionproject as a whole will be overseen by Professor Majorie Van Duursen, at the Free University of Amsterdam.Prof Van Duursen explains: ldquoThere is surprisingly limited knowledge on this issue. We will investigate how exposure to endocrine disruptors during dferent hormone-sensitive phases in a womanrsquos le, from during fetal development in the womb, puberty, and adult stages, can ultimately affect her fertility.Previous research has shown that sperm counts among western men appeared to have halved between  and , with endocrine disruptors cited as a possible cause for the slump along with increasing obesity, smoking and lack of exercise.Read more: Conceiving within six months of miscarriage more likely to be successfulAmong women, the picture is more complicated. Globally, the number of children an average woman gives birth to in her letime has declined from . in  to . by  - but this fertility rate is also a measure of healthcare and social trends.Nonetheless, Prof Fowler believes there is evidence that more women are struggling to conceive.He said: "Its highly controversial. Its one of the areas still under considerable debate and research, but in my view we are swinging to that increasingly becoming correct."Of course its much harder to be sure of fertility in women than men, because obviously in men your can just do a sperm count."Fertility for the woman is much more complicated because it has to extend right to successful pregnancy, so its much harder to prove."One of the big dficulties is that fertility is measured by the numbers of children, but of course theres a strong social element to that as well."But just things likethe chemical makes a woman more likely to be overweight, that will affect her fertility."The researchers in Aberdeen will use samples of human oy tissue taken from children with cancer, as well as tissue samples from IVF patients, and examine the effect of some know endocrine disruptor chemicals on these tissues.They will repeat the experiment in rats and using cells grown in the lab to examine, for example, how these endocrine disruptors affects cells response to the female hormone oestrogen."We will put these three strands together and work out the key pathways that take you from exposure to the chemical to an adverse outcome - which might be reduced fertility," said Prof Fowler.

title: neil-cameron-we-dont-need-neutral-referees-just-better-ones
story: Rangers were in the lead back in August. Remember up at Pittodrie, after the very first game, when Steven Gerrard bemoaned the lsquoworld being againstrsquo his club. Later on came the suggestion Willie Collum was biased, and not in favour of the famous Glasgow. It was a strong case. Or not.But then Neil Lennon claimed Hibs played against  men in a defeat at Celtic Park referee Don Robertson being the extra man.Motherwellrsquos Stephen Robinson wanted officials to go full-time so they could do their jobs properly Steve Clarke has been a constant critic of our men in the middle, while Craig Levein is, well, Craig Levein and loves a moan.Derek McInnes was furious with Andrew Dallas who awarded Celtic a penalty in the League Cup Final for a handball that wasnrsquot a handball which wasnrsquot inside the box but the Aberdeen manager has been knowns to take a pop and his chairman, Stewart Milne, didnrsquot hold back this season when he spoke of the ldquoserious issues surrounding referees.And then came last weekend and those four penalties at Ibrox. Mr Dallas, again, found himself in the centre of a hullabaloo.And to top it all, former ref Steve Conroy insists he was only Jungle Jim among his colleagues, most of the rest were bluenoses, and Tom Boyd, former Celtic captain, insisted ldquoneutral referees must be bought in because our current crop were not good enough and, going by the word he used, biased. Irsquom guessing against Celtic.Ironically, the only one speaking adult was Oran Kearney whose St Mirren team were the ones actually hard done by.And while his players were never going to take a point from Ibrox, that defeat and now a worse goal dference edged them closer to relegation, which will mean sackings and wages being halved. You know. Real stuff.They canrsquot all be right. They canrsquot all be wrong. Andyou look outside the world is still spinning, even after some dodgy decisions which at least gives us all something to talk about. But it feels aswersquove reached rock bottom in terms of how Bobby, Willie, John, Andrew and Steven are viewed.What troubles me still are the less than subtle suggestions from supporters of Rangers and Celtic who have lsquoproofrsquo of mysterious forces out to get them, whether it be Opus Dei or the masons.Oh, and Referee X drinks in the Louden Tavern or Brazen Head. The clubs, incidentally, donrsquot exactly distance themselves with this behaviour.There is a film called lsquoAnyone but Celticrsquo with scenes filmed inside Celtic Park and with a guest appearance from, would you believe, Tom Boyd. You can guess what the plot, pun intended, is.Celtic have won over  trophies, including the last seven in a row. They are one of the most successful football clubs on the planet. Perhaps the film should be retitled lsquoAnyone but Celtic donrsquot win anything in Scotland.rsquoOh, and the idea Rangers are hard done by is laughable. Some of the nonsense which have come by way of the statements shames the club.Right, here goes. The referees in Scotland arenrsquot very good. They are not given enough help by their assistants, fourth official and the SFA. That they arenrsquot allowed to talk in public is a shambles and puts them under even more pressure.The only consistency in decisions made on the park and inside Hampden is that there is gross inconsistency.Every single club believes itrsquos them against everyone . Ask the supporters of Albion Rovers and they will have as many tales of awful officialdom from this season as any those mentioned above.But referees in Scotland are not cheats, which Boyd suggested. However, they need to improve, as do the three colleagues they have with them for Premiership games.If our game is crooked, we need to scrap it and start again. However, these pub bores with an internet  need to prove their accusations with facts. The only fact that counts is human beings make mistakes. Especially when they have whistle in their mouths.

title: scottish-ministers-hail-new-era-amid-plans-for-swathes-of-new-woodland
story: Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing insisted he wanted to see more trees and woodlands covering the country, with Scotland already responsible for nearly  per cent of new trees planted in the UK.It comes after The Herald revealed plans to turn post-industrial derelict sites into urban forests in a bid to find a long-term fix for vacant land in towns and cities.Announcing the launch of Scotlandrsquos Forest Strategy, Mr Ewing reiterated plans to plant , hectares of wood a year from  .He said: ldquoWe can be rightly proud in Scotland of our track record on planting and maintaining trees and forests.ldquoAlready, Scotland is responsible for nearly  per cent of new trees planted in the UK and forestry is a poundbillion industry supporting , jobs all across Scotland.ldquoOur woodlands soak up  million tonnes of CO each year and at the same time, thousands of visitors enjoy health and social benefits from these fantastic natural assets, with over  community groups now involved in working with local woodlands.ldquoI am determined that we build on this success. Tree planting and woodland creation and maintenance must become a shared national endeavour.ldquoThe strategy sets out key objectives for the next ten years and will serve as a framework for everyone who wants to develop Scotlandrsquos modern, dynamic forestry sector.ldquoThe strategy is being launched as we mark  years of public forestry in Scotland, celebrate the benefits achieved for habitats, wildle, communities, people and businesses during that time.The proposals aim to create more forests and woodlands across Scotland by . By , ministers want to see % of the country covered in trees.Some % of Scotland is currently wood or forest ndash higher than the rest of the UK but well below the EU average of %. Trees cover % of France, for example ndash and % of Finland.Mr Ewing said a national group will be established to advise on implementation, alongside two new forestry agencies ndash Scottish Forestry and Forestry  Land Scotland.The Herald previously revealed Glasgow and other towns and cities are looking to plant trees in a bid to fill swathes of derelict land.Councils bosses see this as a cheap way to improve air quality, boost health and even prevent flooding.The Scottish Governmentrsquos strategy notes urban forests also help to ldquoeconomically regenerate degraded urban landscapes, including vacant, derelict and contaminated sites.Carol Evans, director of Woodland Trust Scotland, said: ldquoWoods and trees are at the heart of what makes Scotlandrsquos landscape and environment truly special.ldquoThis new strategy should help all of us better manage and maintain our existing woodland. It should also ensure that we are planting enough native trees in the right places to look after the wildle that depends on them, and to meet our national bioersity targets.She added: ldquoThe new implementation framework should make it clear exactly how to make the strategyrsquos vision a reality, and the new national stakeholder group will definitely provide invaluable support for everyone working to deliver the strategyrsquos outcomes.ldquoThroughout the process we were struck that this was a genuine, open and honest consultation and the Scottish Government listened and engaged with the feedback they received.

title: former-fm-lord-mcconnell-proposes-new-nations-and-regions-department-alongside-uk-council-of-ministers
story: Appearing before the Commons Scottish Affairs Committee inquiring into intergovernmental relations, the former First Minister, now Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale, insisted there needed to be ldquofundamental change in the power structures of the UK, which would include a new Secretary of State for Constitutional Affairs, overseeing a new department, who would be a ldquoDeputy Prime Minister-type inidual, of that standing within Cabinet.Within the department there would be a Scotland Office, a Welsh Office and a Northern Irish Office to handle the territorial s as well as an office for local government because, the Labour peer argued, the English regions were currently under-represented.Alongside that Lord McConnell proposed a UK Council of Ministers to decide on areas where there would be shared legislative responsibility post-Brexit.Crucially perhaps, he suggested each of the four representatives should have equal standing and pointed to the EU, where there was ldquoshared sovereignty. The Council would make joint decisions for the UK in shared areas, giving "proper respect and weight" to all involved on areas such as fishing and agriculture.Askedhis proposal would give the Scottish Government a veto over UK Government decisions, the Labour peer argued majority voting could apply to the decisions of the Council, admitting that would "seriously threaten the sensibilities of the UK Government".He went on: ldquoIf you had these two structures in place, then after  years[of devolution] and after Brexithellipthe UK would look much more like a multi-national governmental structure, which it should be, given the legislative autonomy there now is in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.The former Scottish Labour leader, who was First Minister between  and , made clear the Scotland Office - now officially dubbed the Office of the Secretary of State for Scotland ndash should be abolished and noted how he was "surprised...there was still a Secretary of State for Scotland" following devolution in .His former Government colleague, the Liberal Democrat peer Lord Wallace of Tankerness, backed plans for a UK Council of Ministers to deal with the ldquonew reality of a strengthened devolved settlement.The former Deputy First Minister also questioned the power of the Scotland Office, telling MPs: "I suspect[David Lidington, the Cabinet Office Minister and Theresa Mayrsquos de facto deputy] carries more clout for Scotlands interests than Mr Mundell does no disrespect to Mr Mundell.ldquoI dont think we would be have been any worse off in the early days of devolutionthe Scotland Office had disappeared," he declared.Following the meeting, a UK Government spokeswoman said: "The Secretary of State for Scotland and his office play a vital role in ensuring Scotlands voice is heard at the heart of Whitehall and that the UK Governments responsibilities and activities in Scotland are fully understood."Elsewhere in the committee hearing, Sir Peter Housden, the former head of the civil service in Scotland, recalled how relations between senior members of the UK and Scottish Governments "could not have been more tense" at times during the  independence referendum campaign.John Lamont, the Conservative committee member, asked him: "Thinking back to  and the referendum, is it fair to say that relations between the two governments were quite tense "Sir Peter replied: "Well, interestingly, yes and no. At senior level they could not have been more tense on occasions but nevertheless there were important channels of communication that were being held open."I saw it as my responsibility, with officials in the UK Government, to keep those channels open.Meanwhile, Lord Wallace claimed Tony Blair, the then Prime Minister, "spent most of the time looking out the window" during Joint Ministerial Committee meetings with Scottish Government leaders.He said: "I remember meeting in Edinburgh, in Cardf and by the time it came to the third meeting in Downing Street, I dont think Im exaggerating to say that Tony Blair spent most of the time looking out the window. But actually, nothing much was achieved at them."You were failing to understand the point of them and thats when they fell away and they were only revived after the Scottish National Party came to office in Edinburgh, where theres perhaps arguably a greater need for them."

title: Rosemary Goring  Welcome to Brexit Britain  where common sense is rationed
story: People might joke, or talk shamefacedly about buying one or two extra provisions, but as I go around the supermarket, it certainly seems that trolleys are piled higher than usual. Am I simply imagining it, or is the nation starting to lay down supplies, preparing for siege conditions to begin at one minute past midnight on March  Raised in Dunbar, I am well aware that itrsquos possible to withstand outside pressure on the fridge and pantry for longer than yoursquod think. Black Agnes held off the English who surrounded Dunbar Castle for months by eating frugally and arranging for food to be smuggled in by boat. The th-century equivalent of a Tesco delivery, it slipped under the noses of the English in the dead of night.The perils that face us as a no-deal Brexit looms are historic in quite another way. When Britain opted to leave it was a vote, we were told, for that nebulous but comfortingly empowering idea of ldquotaking back control. Now, as the military has been put on standby to impose curfews, requisition buildings, impose travel bans and crush any sign of unrest or revolt, we could not be further from the conceit of taking things into our own hands. Quite the reverse: almost everything is beyond our control, from the fast-rising cost of imported goods and materials, to the foods available to buy, to the terms and conditions on which our new relationship with Europe will depend.The threat to medicine supplies is alarming enough. When food shortages are also widely anticipated then the entire scenario begins to look like the summer of , as the country battened down the hatches, built Anderson shelters, printed ration books, and dug in for the long and gruelling haul. With the Cold War evacuation plan for the Queen being repurposed for our times ndash doubtless a meandering cruise around the outer isles on a yacht, fresh fish daily on the menu ndash it makes you question the wisdom of blind faithin those who run the country.After watching the BBC documentary about David Cameronrsquos appalling European miscalculation that has led directly to this pass ndash rarely have I felt more angry at the arrogance, incompetence and ignorance of our political leaders ndash I begin to think the days of national government in the best interests of all are long since over. Pandering to a narrow clique of troublemaking dinosaurs, all of them cushioned by wealth and power and privilege, is the reason why we are facing destabilising ndash maybe even crippling ndash social and economic uncertainty. What Winston Churchill would say about our present predicament probably couldnrsquot be printed.I have not yet bought so much as an extra jar of coffee, though there was such a terric deal on loo-roll in one shop the other weekend that we staggered home carrying enough bags to face down an outbreak of dysentery. Wersquore safe on that front for a while. To be honest, it feels a bit over-anxious to listen to scaremongering about emptying shelves, like waving a white flag long before all hope of relief has faded. Yet it is probably sensible to be prepared, even though stockpiling has a bad reputation, suggesting panic rather than a strategic emergency plan.Lettuces, apparently, are going to be like gold dust, but of all the problems Brexit promises, this surely is the least worrying. Some in these parts survived without salad their entire lives and lived to be . Now, however, is the day to rue a garden filled with mosses, clematis and jasmine, rather than with drills of potatoes, leeks and root veg, with a henhouse near the door.Just how empty will the shops become  Around where I live, there are so many farms I doubt wersquoll go long without milk, eggs, potatoes or meat. There is more likelihood of cholesterol overload than starvation.But I might be wrong. So what should go into the Brexit bunker  Irsquoll start by buying logs and oil, followed by a few daysrsquo worth of tins, jars and vacuum-packs. Oatcakes by the kilo, plus ground coffee, tea, wine ndash obviously ndash and the sort of butter that only comes from France, which is as good as cheese.On a visit to Umbria, my husband met a man with an allotment who showed him shelves stacked with bottles of home-pressed olive oil and tomato sugo, ready for autumn. He poured a hearty red wine from his vineyard, while overhead, blackening hams hung from nails. Itrsquos hard to think of anything more comforting than to have your own grocery store within a few feet of the kitchen table. To my mind itrsquos the very definition of taking back control.Read more: May must abandon her Brexit kamikaze mission

title: letters-remainers-should-not-give-up-and-should-become-returners
story: Lying being not only acceptable but effective, the Brexiters cannot give up their compulsion. For instance consider the Conservative MP Daniel Kawczynskirsquos distortion of the truth regarding our share of Marshall Plan aid .However, much more serious is the fact that Mrs May is either distorting our unwritten constitution or is seeking to ldquorewrite it to meet the needs of her eternally discredited party. She claimed last week that she opposed the Grieve and Cooper amendments on the grounds that they ldquowould allow Parliament to usurp the proper role of the Executive. This is utter nonsense. I understand that ldquo there is any democratic legitimacy in our system, it lies with the democratically elected MPs. As Edmund Burke said ldquoYour representative owes you ... his judgment and he betrays, instead of serving you,he sacrices it to your opinionhellip"How should we Remainers react to the looming catastrophe  I suggest that we do so by refusing to give up and by becoming Returners. As Will Hutton has said, ldquothe British are culturally and philosophically Europeans the consequence being that many of the  million who voted Remain will surely have no intention of giving up that heritage, ever.John Milne, Ardgowan Drive, Uddingston.AS we get closer to the clf edge of a No Deal Brexit, we have to ponder the possible predicament of the UK.Despite the optimistic noises of the May contingent, rather like whistling in the dark, that the EU will relent and offer changes to the Withdrawal Agreement, we could well see ourselves out in the cold from March .It is all rather reminiscent of the Prodigal Son, a story where a young man, guaranteed an inheritance, decided he wanted independence to make his own way in the world.Many of us know how that ended. He squandered his opportunities, fell into hard times and came back chastened to his father who forgave him his errors and welcomed him home.Could the same fate await the UK, which demands sovereignty and striking out on its own I doubt that the EU will be as charitable and forgiving as the father of the prodigal sonwe fall on hard times and come back chastened, seeking our former relationship with the EU.Denis Bruce, Rannoch Gardens, Bishopbriggs.ITS increasingly clear there wont be a second EU referendum, plus, while Article  may be delayed, it wont be revoked. So its Theresa Maysdeal or No Deal ndash thats the most likely binary choice available to our  MPs. Nicola Sturgeon opposes Theresa Mays compromise deal while absolutely insisting no deal is the very worst outcome for Scotland ndash so how are her  SNP MPs going to vote in the Commons  Alongside Jacob Rees-Moggs ardent Brexiters for the probable chaos of No Deal ndash or, albeit reluctantly, for Theresa Mays compromise  Both are politically untenable to the SNP. But is Ms Sturgeon capable of putting aside her Scotland versus the rest of the UK games and puerile party-political point-scoring, to do whats best for the people of Scotland Martin Redfern,Woodcroft Road, Edinburgh.CHRISTOPHER Idesays there are ious reasons people voted Leave but the fact is Brexiters rubbished the benefits of EU membership and called well-informed warnings "Project Fear". Yet our membership was central to the Thatcher sales pitch which led to the opening of Nissanrsquos Sunderland car plant.Even on Sunday, when Nissan itself explained that Brexit was a factor in its decision to build the new SUV in Japan, airtime was still given to Jacob Rees-Mogg to deny this though he has no car industry expertise or experience and his Somerset constituency could hardly be further away from the north-east.As an ordinary minister, Theresa May admitted a great deal of inward investment depended on us being part of the EU. Sadly, as Prime Minister she tried to hide her own Governmentrsquos assessments of the economic damage Brexit would do ndash especially to the north-east of England ndash ploughing on asthe  vote was sacred.Rev Dr John Cameron, Howard Place, St Andrews.AT the weekend I was watching The Italian Joband I was struck by the last scene and how it was very like the current Brexit situation. There you had Michael Caine inching towards the gold bars and the bus precariously balanced on the clf edge, telling his gang of English football supporters to move back to counter balance his weight and telling them that no-one should try to get off the bus. As the balance shts and the gold slides further away to the end of the coach Cane turns to his companions and say "wait a minute lads, Ive got an idea".And the scene shts to the outside and the soundtrack comes up with the theme song We are The Self Preservation Society, whichJacob Rees-Mogg, David Cameron et al had been on the coach is highly appropriate.It found it amusing and quite apposite regarding the position we are in. The fact the characters in the film heist are all English and all the foreign chaps are either evil or incompetent or both sounds like Boris et al speaking about those EU coves trying to do down the crooks. All that was missing was Caine in leopard-print kitten heels and we would be in Brussels.Ronald H Oliver, Woodside Road, Elie.Read more:IM truly at a loss at trying to understand our friends and neighbours, the Irish.One hundred years ago they demanded "their right" to be an independent sovereign nation making its own laws and economic decisions.Is it not somewhat ironical and somewhat galling when Great Britain has voted to take back its right to make its laws and economic decisions again, we now have a situation where the Irish Taoiseach and his unelected EU friends in Brussels are endeavouring to obstruct Britains democratic decision to do so.Ironic, nest pas mes amis Robin Gilmour,Mosspark Avenue, Glasgow.MUCH is being made of the sense of loyalty between Ireland and the EU and now with the United States. However, the loyalty shown by the UK to Ireland in making a pound billion contribution towards helping it during the financial crisis despite the UKs own problems seems to have been quickly forgotten.Paul Lewis, Guardwell Crescent, Edinburgh.Read more: PM must abort Brexit kamikaze mission

title: campaigners-call-for-right-to-food-to-be-enshrined-in-scots-law
story: The Scottish Food Coalitionhas said that everyone should have access to healthy sustainable foodstuffs for themselves and their families and wants ministers to step in to ensure it becomes law.The Scottish Government is currently consulting on the next steps for its Good Food Bill, which aims to widen access to healthy local foods and ensure the industry remains sustainable.But the SFC said that the countryrsquos food system is failing to meet the needs of both Scotlandrsquos people and the environment. It warned that more than one-third of working Scots worry about putting food on the table., while there are growing numbers relying on foodbanksIt also claims that methods of food production have harmed wildle, adversely affected soil and water quality, and increased climate-warming emissions.Professor Mary Brennan, chairwoman of the Scottish Food Coalition, said: ldquoI urge everyone to respond to this consultation, the outcomes of which will shape how the Scottish food system is managed for generations to come.ldquoScotland has an exciting opportunity to be world leading in placing food at the heart of all decision making."By doing so we can improve the quality, healthfulness, and environmental sustainability of our food while ensuring that those who produce and prepare it do so under fair, safe and secure conditions.:New project to tackle child poverty in Scotland as , struggle to feed familiesThe right to food would guarantee that people in Scotland can access enough to eat. It could prevent benefits agencies from imposing penaltiesit meant a claimantrsquos food supply was threatened.Dr Sheila George, food policy manager for WWF Scotland, added: ldquoGlobally, food production and consumption are key drivers of wildle declines and climate change."Scotlandrsquos rich natural resources and less intensive farming systems mean we have huge potential to do things dferently here, but we arenrsquot quite there yet.ldquoThe impacts of the current food system are cross-cutting and the solutions need to be too, which is why this consultation is so welcome."The Good Food Nation Bill could be the catalyst we need to join up our broken food system and make healthy, environmentally sustainable food the norm.The SFC is a broad-based alliance of civil society organisations working on issues of health, environment, workersrsquo rights, animal welfare, social justice and food poverty.:Christmas at the food bank: You can see the panic in the childrens eyes#Members include RSPB Scotland, Unite, Unison, WWF, Oxfam, Soil Association, the Poverty Alliance, the Alliance for Long-Term Care, Trussell Trust, Fareshare and Nourish Scotland.It has called for the Good Food Bill to address five key issues, including the right to food, statutory targets in areas such as food poverty and waste, a national food plan, local authoritiesrsquo responsibilities and a cross-cutting national food plan.Lorraine Tulloch, Programme Lead for Obesity Action Scotland said: ldquoFor too long the people in Scotland have been suffering the health consequences of a poor diet."If we want to address the accessibility, affordability and acceptability of a healthy diet then we need to see joined up action across the whole food system."We must grab the opportunity that the Good Food Nation Bill offers to change our food system for the better and ultimately improve the health of the nation.Jackson Cullinane from Unite the Union said: ldquoThis consultation is very welcome and long overdue. It is important that it considers ideas and proposals on the broad range of issues relative to good food provision, including the need to tackle food poverty, improve health and ensure that workers across the food chain have decent wages, conditions and the highest possible standards of health and safety. ldquoA spokesman for the Scottish Governmentsaid: lsquoWe remain committed to introduce legislation in this parliament to underpin the excellent work already being done to deliver our Good Food Nation ambition."To support these aims, the Good Food Nation Proposals for Legislation consultation was launched on  December  with the focus on a straightforward framework placing responsibilities on Scottish Ministers and selected public bodies with regard to food. ldquoThe First Ministerrsquos Advisory Group on Human Rights Leadership reported in December, and recommended a new statutory human rights framework. The Scottish Government will now establish a National Task Force to take forward the recommendation.":Retailers warn no-deal Brexit could lead to empty supermarket shelves and higher prices#He added: "The Task Force will be asked to consider all internationally-recognised human rights, including the right to food.rsquo

title: egypt-and-east-asia-focus-of-new-galleries-at-national-museum-to-open-this-weekend
story: Two galleries, one focussing on Ancient Egypt, the other on East Asia, will open to the public this weekend in Edinburgh, as well as a new display of the art of ceramics.Ancient Egypt Rediscovered, which covers  years of history and contains many objects not seen in public before, marks  years since the first ancient Egyptian items entered the museum collections.The exhibition also includes a casing stone from the Great Pyramid of Giza, an object that aroused the interest of Egyptian authorities when they heard of its inclusion.However Dr Gordon Rintoul, director of the NMS, said that the museums were confident that owned the casing stone legally.The head of the repatriation department at Egypts ministry of antiquities has said it wants to inspect all the documentation about the stone, brought to the UK in , and said that it could be open to a repatriation request.The Egyptian gallery at the NMS includes two mummies, a man and a woman, as well as other funerary objects, weapons, treasures and jewellery, as well as several interactive objects, including a voyage into the afterle.The Exploring East Asia Gallery features a Samurai armour not previously on show, and looks at the cultures of China, Japan and Korea.Mr Rintoul said: "I think the Egypt gallery will be very popular, but what makes it dferent from other Egypt galleries will be is that they tend to focus on mummies and pyramids in a very narrow sense, but of course that is just a tiny bit of what characterised the ancient Egyptian civilisation."Most people dont realise that period lasted for  years - there is more time between the pyramids and Cleopatra than there is between Cleopatra and us."What we have tried to do is tell that story of ancient Egypt as a civilisation: how they lived, who they were, the fact that it was colonised by people from the south and the north, that is wasnt a static society, it was ever-changing."Our collections are very wide ranging and we can tell that story."Dr Rintoul said that only some of the key items have been on display: the casing stone has been in the museums possession since  but not shown in public before.Around % of the items are being displayed for the first time in a generation, or longer.The Samurai armour in the East Asia exhibit, from the early th century, has been conserved and looks, he said "like it was made yesterday."He added: "We have tried to make it personal, so a lot of the caskets and so on have a story behind them - the ancient Egyptians were people, and we have tried wherever possible to give that human story."The NMS are expecting the new galleries to be popular with family visits.Of the pyramid casing stone, Dr Rintoul said: "The Egyptian authorities did not know we had it, we had not displayed it before, it was not known about, so I think they just reacted to this item suddenly appearing."We gave them all the details, how and when it was acquired, and it featured in books published at the time, and even in media at the time."It is perfectly clear, it has been here since , and perfectly legitimately here."In , Charles Piazzi Smyth, the Astronomer Royal of Scotland, began a programme of research including the first largely accurate survey of the Great Pyramid.In doing so, he had the permission of the Viceroy of Egypt and the assistance of the Egyptian Antiquities Service.The stone was brought to the UK by Waynman Dixon in  and transported to Piazzi Smyth in Edinburgh.An Egyptian law, of , bans the trade or export of antiquities.Dr Rintoul said that although the major changes to the museum building on Chambers Street are over, exhibitions and displays will change and be refreshed.It is expected that at some point the Scottish exhibits in the National Museum will be revamped.

title: 1-shopping-centre-in-kirkcaldy-sells-for-310000-at-auction
story: The Postings centre in Kirkcaldy was snapped up at an auction in London following a bidding war by investors.:Glasgow shopping centre staging MASSIVE Baby Shark danceThe , sq ft centre is made up of  stores, of which  are empty, and a -space car park. It generates pound, of income a year.Its reserve price had been set at just pound after it became a casualty of the downturn in high street shopping.Investment company Columbia Threadneedle, which owns the centre, said they had decided to sell up as the centre no longer fits in with their investment strategy.At the auction at the Berkeley Hotel in Knightsbridge, the first bid for the centre was pound. It quickly jumped to pound, and it was eventually bought by an anonymous telephone bidder for pound, after they outbid a person bidding online.The buyer will also have to pay legal costs of pound, and complete the sale by February .Duncan Moir, who conducted the bidding for auctioneers Allsop, said: ldquoThis is an interesting lot and there has been a bit of interest in it. We have a very motivated seller and we have to sell it today. All that shopping centre for that price.The centre, which opened in , has struggled to recover after itsmain tenant Tesco closed its supermarket in .It is thought any new buyer may view the purchase as an opportunity to demolish and redevelop the site. In a statement, Columbia Threadneedle said: ldquoWe acquired the Postings more than  years ago as an incomeproposition and it has since been re-positioned as a development opportunity, which does not fit the holding fundrsquos investment strategy.Current stores at the centre include Farmfoods, Fe Council and Lloyds Pharmacy.:intu Braehead set to house new MAC Cosmetics shop in surprise announcementOne property expert said that the shopping centre was still ldquotoo expensive despite its bargain-basement price.He said: ldquoThere are going to be a number of locations where, due to the liability of business rates and the cost of demolition, there is a negative site value until the shopping centre can be demolished and built back into an economic use. There are places where these alternative uses may not stack up either.Columbia Threadneedle, said management was ldquoworking closely with Fe Council.

title: garment-factory-to-be-home-for-channel-4-in-glasgow
story: Channel  says it is in "advanced negotiations" with Castleforge Partners to lease just over , sq ft in The Garment Factory building, and will use it as its new Creative Hub.The broadcaster plans to lease the space on the first floor of the building, in Montrose Street in the city centre, which has recently undergone a refurbishment.The Garment Factory is a large building in the Merchant City Central Conservation Area.Built in , it was originally the garment factory of J  W Campbell.Channel  intends to take up the space in the building from late .Jonathan Allan, Channel rsquos chief commercial officer said: "Wersquove seen a range of incredibly impressive potential options across the city as a home for our new Creative Hub in Glasgow."However, The Garment Factory stood out as an iconic building which would give us the flexibility of space we need and the proximity to other creative businesses and services in Glasgow city centre.Alistair Urquhart, associate director, CBRE, which is negotiating the deal, said: ldquoThe Garment Factory is a modern and unique building which will provide an ideal fit for Channel ."Having advised Channel  on a series of property related matters we are delighted to be close to securing the first of its regional hubs."Channel  announced in October that Glasgow would be the location of one of its new Creative Hubs, alongside another in Bristol, with Leeds named as a new National HQ.

title: what-is-the-role-of-the-carbon-reduction-fund-in-helping-climate-change
story: Scotlandrsquos universities play a fundamental part in the le of the country and are erse and complex institutions. Between them they have five medical schools, three dental schools and two vet schools. There is an art school, a conservatoire and an agricultural college. But no matter what the size, the speciality or the location, Scotlandrsquos  universities are committed to reducing their carbon footprint.As for any other business or institution change comes at a cost and a lack of funding can mean the dference between a carbon reduction project happening and it remaining a well-intentioned idea in a strategic plan. It was a desire to help remove this barrier that led the Scottish Funding Councilto introduce its University Carbon Reduction Fund.Launched in , the fund has two strands one that supports large-scale programmes from pound, to pound million and one that supports smaller-scale energy efficiency projects. In the first year of the funding scheme  applications were funded to a tune of just over pound million.Amongst the larger projects was funding towards the University of Strathclydersquos pound million Combined Heat and PowerDistrict Heating system, itself part of a long-term, pound million investment in the universityrsquos infrastructure which is set to reduce its carbon-dioxide emissions by , tonnes and save pound million a year.SFCrsquos University Carbon Reduction Fund provided pound, to improve the efficiency of the existing heat network. Central to the improvements was the need to balance out iations in demand and prevent heat being vented into the atmosphere when demand was low. This is being achieved by the installation of a huge , litre thermal store. The funding also paid for over two kilometers of piping to extend the universityrsquos district heating network.Dr Roddy Yarr, Strathclydersquos Assistant Director , said: ldquoThese new works will extend and optimise the district energy network to generate additional financial and carbon savings. The university has been working in partnership with SFC on this and other innovative schemes and this funding is helping to transform the way that the university manages its energy costs and is able to tackle climate change.In the East of Scotland, a pound, funding investment at Heriot-Watt University illustrates a more typical package of measures underway to make Scottish universities greener. Designed to reduce the universityrsquos energy spend and carbon emissions from heating, it focusses on upgrading boiler plants in three student halls of residence. Once installed, the upgraded system will save an estimated % on heating bills and contribute to a % reduction in emissions.Elsewhere, projects are of the type that any energy-conscious homeowner would recognise ndash but scaled up to a large organisation level. At Abertay University inefficient fluorescent lighting is being replaced by modern LED fittings with intelligent controls to make sure lights go off in unoccupied areas or when natural daylight is providing enough illumination. New lighting systems at the University of Dundee include improving the working environment in laboratories in a scheme that will reduce energy consumption by  percent. At Edinburgh Napier University three more of its campuses will have solar  electricity systems thanks to a pound, funding injection from SFC.Karen Watt, Chief Executive of the Scottish Funding Council, said: ldquoScotlandrsquos Climate Change Act stipulates an % reduction in our CO emissions by . The Scottish Funding Councilrsquos University Carbon Reduction Fund is helping universities to lead the way to that target. The fund is encouraging ambition and innovation as well as helping big organisations to take practical measures to effect change.The Heraldrsquos Climate for Change initiative supports efforts being made by the ScottishGovernmentwith key organisations and campaign partners. title: derek-mackay-denies-being-dishonest-over-extra-budget-cash
story: The Finance Secretary was criticised by Tory MSP Murdo Fraser for failing to tell MSPs he received an eleventh-hour windfall of poundm from the UK Treasury.Mr Mackay said he learned of the Barnett formula lsquoconsequentialsrsquo on Burns Night, six days before MSPs held a crunch vote on the   budget.However he did not tell Parliament until after he had already struck a budget deal with the Scottish Greens that involved giving poundm of the money to councils.At Holyroodrsquos finance committee, Mr Fraser said thatall the parties had known about the money, it could have changed the political calculus.Mr Mackay said he first learned on Friday January , and his officials sought clarication from the Treasury the following Monday, three days before the vote.Asked by Mr Fraser why he didnrsquot tell Parliament about the money, Mr Mackay said: ldquoI did tell the parliament in Stage One of the budget when I addressed the chamber [on January ].Asked why he didnrsquot tell parliament immediately given the ongoing budget discussions with the Greens and other parties, Mr Mackay said: ldquoThatrsquos a ludicrous question, as Murdo Fraser well knows, because I update parliament and all the expectations around transparency.ldquoAs soon as I was able to, I informed parliament.ldquoAs it happens that was Stage One of the budget.But Mr Fraser said Mr Mackay could have made the information available through a parliamentary answer on January .Mr Mackay accused parties of ldquoideological obtuseness during the budget, and suggested Mr Fraser was ldquokicking himself for the Tories not engaging more constructively.Mr Fraser hit back: ldquoSurely the opposition parties would be a bit more constructive in terms of the budgetyou, as cabinet secretary, were not being essentially dishonest about the resources at your disposal, and concealing from them and concealing from parliament the extent of the spending envelope that might be available.ldquoThis is a government that is anything but transparent. Itrsquos a government which is concealing from parliament, and concealing from those who are in good faith trying to negotiate the budget, the facts of the availability of funds.ldquoSurely you need to reflect on this cabinet secretary Committee convener Bruce Crawford advised Mr Fraser to watch his language.Mr Mackay said he had been ldquohonest, transparent and clear throughout.Mr Fraser said later: ldquoDerek Mackay today confirmed that he and Patrick Harvie were bailed out at the last minute by [Chancellor] Philip Hammond.ldquoDespite demanding independence at every turn, their deal only got through thanks to the United Kingdomrsquos system of pooling and sharing resources. What complete hypocrites.ldquoWorse, Mr Mackay failed to tell parliament or any opposition parties of his windfall before he presented his Budget last week ndash despite knowing about it  days before. He has behaved in an underhand and dishonest fashion, which does the SNP no credit whatsoever.

title: bins to be collected once every three weeks in new council strategy
story: Aberdeenshire residents will be encouraged to become recycling champions with the introduction of a controversial three-weekly collection programme.The revised waste strategy for all , properties in the Shire was approved in a - vote by the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee despite an alternative option from Peterhead SNP councillor Stephen Smith who said it was “too much, too soon”.From April next year, households will have weekly kerbside collections for one of three bins including a  litre bin for paper and card and  litre bin for metals, plastics and cartons.However under the new scheme, the existing general residual bin for non-recyclable waste will be signicantly reduced to a  litre capacity.Councillors were told by waste director Philip McKay that while it was a considerable reduction, the service felt it “should be manageable for most households”.He added that while a three-weekly non-recyclable waste collection might feel a bit daunting to residents initially – as did the move from weekly to fortnightly collections in Aberdeenshire a few years ago – experience from other Scottish local authorities showed that it is workable and can lead to a signicant increase in recycling rates.Mr McKay also stressed that given the larger recycling capacity provided in the favoured option, it provided “more flexibility in the future” for the addition of other recyclable materials without the need for additional recycling containers.Councillors were told that the scheme had the potential to save waste services £, per year at the lower end of the scale and even morethere was a higher uptake in recycling.However, Peterhead councillor Stephen Smith said the proposals as they stood were a step too far for North-east communities.In a bid to address concerns about the potential impact of any necessary changes to the waste strategy, he proposed that instead of using a -litre bin for three weekly collections, Aberdeenshire Council instead do what has happened in much of the rest of Scotland and keep the  litre bin for three weekly waste collections, with new  litre bins – which are expected to be funded in large part by ‘Zero Waste Scotland’ – being used for paper and card recycling for a transitional period.Councillor Smith’s proposal – which he claimed would have saved an estimated £, annually – followed confirmation from council officers that such a proposal would be compatible with Zero Waste Scotland’s requirements for helping to fund the cost of the new bins required.But council depute leader Peter Argyle warned against “changing horses” halfway through the programme as it would only lead to confusion.He told the committee that with an imminent landfill ban on biodegradable waste “coming down the tracks” by , it was title: posting parcels to eu countries after brexit
story: Q: I have an online business with  per cent international sales, but neither Royal Mail nor the Post Office can sayCN customs labels are going to be required for the EEA EU.Any idea A CN is a customs document, used when goods are being transported overseas. It contains a description and value of the item being posted along with the country of origin. It is valid for items up to £, while a CN label is the same, but for goods worth £ and over.Electronic customs data needs to be supplied whenever a parcel is required to go through Customs clearance. Currently this is applicable to only countries outside of the EU.However, Royal Mails official advice to customers is that they DO prepare to send data to all countries following Brexit.Readers questions: Will I need a new passport after Brexit As you will know, at the minute theres no need for customs declarations or clearance on anything you post to EU destinations. If we leave with a withdrawal agreement it is likely that nothing will change, at least during the transition period until .Butthere is a no-deal Brexit then the current guidance from HMRC is that the same rules will apply to UK businesses exporting to the EU as do to non-EU countries from March .This means that your goods will require a CN or CN form.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The CE safety symbol belongs to the EU"  UK plans new safety certicate mark for when we leave EU viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MILN | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MILN | Article Teaser"

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: wine drinkers could be seeing red over brexit price rises
story: The Journal of Wine Economics featured an industry study that says that the amount customers pay could increase by up to  per cent by  in the event of a hard Brexit, or  per cent in terms of a softer Brexit.British vineyards could benefit however.According to a report by WSTA, the Wine and Spirit Trade Association,  percent of wine drunk in the UK is imported. Of this half is produced in the EU, while the remainder comes from Australia, USA, Chile, Argentina, South Africa and New Zealand. There are concerns thatthe right measures are not put in place it could stop imports from crossing the border, which has lead some retailers to stock up on bottles in advance.The WSTA has been advising members for more than a year that they should increase their stock by  per cent as a starting point in case of a no deal Brexit.Miles Beale, chief executive of the Wine and Spirit Trade Association, said: ldquoSince the Referendum, the WSTA has campaigned consistently for a deal with the EU that delivers frictionless trade in goods, with no additional tarfs or costs.ldquoIf the UK ends up with a no-deal Brexit then wine businesses will have to cope with additional tarfs as well as another duty rise - which is highly likely to end up full square in the consumerrsquos lap, bumping up wine prices to an all-time high.ldquoCurrently there are no tarfs on wines from the EU, Chile and South Africa. A no deal Brexit would result in the introduction of tarfs, estimated to cost UK wine importing businesses over £ million a year.ldquoThe introduction of no deal Brexit tarfs would be a double blow for wine businesses after the Chancellor elected to single out wine for a duty rise at the Autumn Budget.From February  the duty on a bottle of wine went up by p, but add a tarf to the duty rise and VAT and this means an average priced bottle of wine, which today costs £., will cost £. in the event of no deal.Read more: How will Brexit affect your travel plans  This is an extra p a bottle more than consumers paid before the referendum result when an average priced bottle of wine was £..There could be some positive benefits for British vineyards however.It is believed that British wines will seem less expensive than its European counterparts as retailers wonrsquot be forced to hike prices because of rate or tarfs.However, British vineyards could be hit with the lack of skilled workers from the EU and vital agricultural funding streams. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
